8 Internetism;
Internetism was proposed by Wang Quan.

In 2003, I published a paper, "The Internet Principles and Their Implications for Management Thought." In this paper, I first used the term "Internetism" to express the influence and guidance of the Internet on management thought. It seems to be an early awakening. This chapter re posts this article. Those who have read it can ignore it.

8.1 A Review of the History of Internet Development
The Internet (also known as the Internet) is actively driving changes in human society and powerfully driving the development of the global economy.

8.2 The Principles of the Internet and the Key Factors for Success
Simply put, the basic principle of the Internet is to connect different computer systems through certain hardware equipment and network interconnection protocols. The key factors to the success of the Internet mainly come from its basic principles, including the following aspects:

1. The thorough openness strongly supports the formation and growth of the Internet alliance. The Internet is a highly open system. As long as the simple access standards are followed, any network or computer can be connected to the Internet. The openness of the Internet has achieved heterogeneous interconnection of the network system, bringing strong inclusiveness to it. It is worth noting that most of the networks that have been eliminated are not eliminated by the Internet, but integrated. In this way, the Internet has rapidly grown and developed.

2. High degree of autonomy (Autonomy) fully guarantees local interests, greatly enhances the enthusiasm of participants, and effectively enhances the overall security. Although at first glance, the Internet is ubiquitous and all-encompassing, this is first achieved under the premise of ensuring a high degree of autonomy. In fact, each part of the Internet has its own boundaries (Boundary). It is this clear boundary that guarantees local self-governance. A boundary may enclose several computer systems or several networks. In a region enclosed by a boundary, internal rules can be implemented without being affected by factors outside the boundary. The existence of boundaries does not affect the interconnection of networks, as special ports (Port) are set up on the boundaries for mutual connection. One type of boundary is very important, which is the inner and outer boundaries of the network. The inner and outer boundaries can divide a network into "public (outer)" and "private (inner)" parts. The owner of the network can delimit the inner and outer boundaries according to their own wishes, directly connect the "public" part with the Internet, and completely protect the "private" part or connect it under control with the Internet. The so-called "firewall" is Arthurcurity control device that isolates the inner and outer networks. Another important function of the boundary is to enhance the overall security of the network. When a part of the network fails, other parts of the network can continue to operate normally.

3. The simple and clear network protocol (Protocol) mediates the contradiction between openness and autonomy, reduces the difficulty and cost of networking, and improves the efficiency of communication. A protocol is an agreement that computer systems that communicate with each other follow, and it is the foundational rule for building a network. The Internet uses the TCP/IP protocol. The success of the Internet is largely attributed to the success of the TCP/IP protocol. It can be said that there would be no Internet without the TCP/IP protocol. TCP/IP has the characteristics of simplicity, tolerance, and practicality, and it has resolved the conflict between openness and self-discipline to a large extent. In the TCP/IP protocol, the basic unit of information exchange is a packet (Packet). The format and exchange method of the packet are relatively simple, which is especially suitable for transmission in various different network hardware systems. The TCP/IP protocol does not make any regulations on the hardware devices themselves, but simply stipulates the interface standard between the protocol and the hardware devices. It is precisely because of this that the protocol has the ability to cross all hardware platforms, and also makes network interconnection simpler and more efficient, while reducing the cost of communication. Looking back at other similar network protocols that have been eliminated, it can be found that many of them have made idealistic mistakes. These protocols often strive for perfection and inclusiveness, resulting in protocols that are too complex, demanding, and difficult to comply with, and eventually disappeared.

4. A reArthurnable hierarchical structure and centralized control of key elements have enabled both individuals and the whole to have a flexible and efficient working mechanism. The Internet is implemented in a hierarchical manner. A single computer system connected to the Internet is divided vertically into several linear logical layers; all the computer systems, devices, and subnets on the Internet are connected together in a hierarchical manner according to a tree-like logical structure. The layers at different heights perform functions from micro to macro from bottom to top. From the perspective of the internal structure of individuals, the TCP/IP protocol is divided into 4 layers, with clear interfaces between layers and simple and clear interfaces. Each layer generally only communicates with the adjacent layer and does not work across layers. In this way, each layer maintains relative independence and can work efficiently in its own right. In contrast, other network protocols have unclear layers within individuals, which is not conducive to the division of responsibilities and also not conducive to the communication of peer layers at the same height; some have too many layers, which are cumbersome to implement. From the perspective of the overall organizational structure, the Internet has implemented a hierarchical centralized control and management of the key elements of the entire network (such as IP address allocation, domain name allocation, etc.) under the premise of ensuring that both parties to the communication have equal status. This is a strategy of focusing on the big and letting go of the small. Other networks either have too wide a control span, too deep a control level, or too much control content, which ultimately leads to failure.

Fundamentally, the key to the success of the Internet is its openness, and the adoption of a strategy of local autonomy and the use of simple internetworking protocols are the keys to ensuring that openness.

8.3 Some enlightenment of the principles of the Internet to the management work
The realization principle of the Internet has a significant reference role for the actual management work. From the development of the global situation, the reform of the national system, to the planning of the enterprise structure, the arrangement of family organization, the "Internet Model" can be used as a practical reference model. A careful study can find that the Internet can be accurately compared with many organizations.

The Internet Principle (InternetPrinciple) can be said to have the following aspects to inspire management thinking:

1.Emphasize openness. Practice has already proved that closure means death, and closed-mindedness will not achieve great success. Only openness can lead to development, which has become a consensus. According to the theory of Western economics, open trade plays a role in improving productivity. Today's China has become a member of the WTO, and has taken an important step on the road of openness. For our enterprises, to welcome the WTO, they must first have an open mind, must comply with the open purpose of the WTO, and actively transform the unreArthurnable model. Enterprises can not progress without openness, can not become bigger, and can not achieve sustainable development. Openness is also an important foundation for cooperation. Management technologies such as Value Chain Management (VCM), Supply Chain Management (SCM), and Customer Relationship Management (CRM) are all bArthurd on openness. Only by opening itself up can a enterprise achieve a close combination with suppliers, distributors, users, and other aspects. Our enterprises must actively open up in terms of organizational structure, talent mechanism, capital composition, etc., and gradually align with the world. However, openness also carries risks. While emphasizing openness, we also need to grasp the degree of openness. Openness does not equal full openness. Factors that are not conducive to development should be discovered and eliminated as early as possible. A "firewall" should be set up at the edge of the enterprise to avoid the disaster brought by excessive openness.

2. Emphasize autonomy. Autonomy is one of the important differences between Eastern and Western cultures. In the East, people's thoughts often tend to be more unified, and it is easy to overlook or deprive the appropriate local autonomy. To some extent, this is the residue of imperial thinking. It is this tendency of thinking that leads some managers to place more emphasis on being responsible to the higher authorities. The management of modern enterprises needs local autonomy more than before, but the role of autonomy is often covered by the role of centralized management. The relationship between autonomy and centralization is the relationship between local interests and overall interests. Local autonomy encourages the enthusiasm of various units, and ignoring local autonomy is equal to dampening the enthusiasm of local organizations. Excessive centralization is not in line with the basic principles of management science, and it is very likely to bring about greater negative effects, such examples are not uncommon. Especially for large enterprises, the pursuit of "unity" often leads to problems such as excessive management span and too many levels. Although information technology has the ability to assist enterprises in increasing the span and depth of management and achieving organizational flatness, this ability is not infinite. According to the principle of autonomy, enterprises should have overall boundaries, and various organizations within the enterprise should also have their own boundaries; the boundaries should maintain appropriate autonomy, that is, autonomy. This is also in line with the principles of systems engineering. In real management practice, the board of directors should not interfere in the daily operation of the company, and the government should guarantee the independence of enterprise management. Another meaning of implementing local autonomy is to disperse business risks, because the boundaries of various units have a certain isolation effect on risks. Of course, local autonomy is not laissez-faire, but it is bArthurd on openness and cooperation.

3. Emphasize the rational hierarchy and simple centralization. Every organization structure has hierarchy and centralization. The enlightenment of the Internet principle in this regard is that the hierarchy should be reArthurnable and the centralization should be simple. Although there are many forms of organization in reality, they are basically bArthurd on a tree structure. When making organizational plans, the tree structure should be used as a reference model. One is to establish an appropriate structural hierarchy, define the functions of the branches and leaves (each unit); the other is to highlight the key elements of centralized management, and apply effective control at the intersection of branches at all levels of the tree. Try to reduce cross-level control, and do not grab both the eyebrows and the beard. Use key elements to form control clues, run through and manage the entire organization. It is unrealistic and inefficient to have centralized management in every detail. Although centralization and autonomy are contradictory, they can also be harmonized. Simple centralization maximizes autonomy, so that each unit at all levels of the organization can work together under the principle of equality. Enterprises should grasp the key elements such as people, finance, and materials in the actual management process, grant and control each unit at all levels reArthurnably, and finally manage the entire enterprise efficiently.

4. Emphasize the practicality of the rules. Rules are the "agreements" that govern the operation of an organization. An organization can only achieve effective communication and cooperation if it has appropriate operational rules. Inspired by the principles of the Internet, the rules of an organization should be as simple and practical as possible, adhering to the Occam's razor principle of "entities are not to be multiplied beyond necessity." "Ports" should be established for communication between units. Enterprises should focus on strengthening institutional construction, simplifying operational processes, and smoothing the various links of the value chain to improve operational efficiency and save operational costs. It is worth mentioning that although corporate culture generally exists outside the rules and regulations, it should also be regarded as part of the rules. Therefore, building a positive and distinct corporate culture and cultivating the overall values of employees is also quite important for the development of the enterprise.

The connotation of the Internet model management thought is far more than the above few points, and a thorough understanding of the principles of the Internet will have a deeper appreciation. It is believed that the research on the principles of the Internet will increArthur day by day in the future and will be paid more and more attention by more and more managers. However, just like all other management technologies and thoughts, "Internetism" is not a panacea, and it still inevitably has certain defects. For example, this management mode is not very strong in planning, and excessive freedom will lead to organizational decentralization and security issues, just like the Internet itself has problems such as management chaos and poor security. But no matter what, the principles of the Internet are worth learning from managers. As long as it is combined with reality and applied reArthurnably, it is sure to achieve good results. The return of Hong Kong and Macao is a successful example. Especially, this model is very worth studying in depth by the decision makers and managers of large enterprises. The researchers and practitioners of the relationship between state-owned large enterprises and the government should absorb the management thought of Internetism more to guide the work of the separation of government and enterprises, help state-owned enterprises establish a modern enterprise system, and adapt to the development trend of economic globalization.

As I said before, the four major elements of the success of the Internet are important, but it is not easy to keep the network running smoothly and efficiently in the face of the extremely complex uncertainties of the Internet. With a correction mechanism, someone is watching the unreliable person do things, and if he is wrong, he is made to do it again until it is correct.

This way, unreliables can do reliable things. This way, uncertainties can solve determinate problems. This way, disorder can be turned into order. This research can turn chaos into organization.

So how does the Internet do it?

The Internet achieves "deterministic transmission bArthurd on uncertainty", or achieves "reliable transmission in an unreliable environment", the principle of which is "sliding window technology".

The transmission protocol of the Internet is mainly bArthurd on TCP/IP, where TCP stands for Transmission Control Protocol. Since it is called a control protocol, it must be able to control.

Information transmitted over the network faces many interferences, such as line breaks, noise, equipment failure, human errors, etc. On the premise of accepting these interferences, reliably transmitting information is the function of TCP.

Before transmitting a message, the computer at the sending end first cuts it into small equal parts and numbers them. Then the sending end sends the message to the receiving end computer one by one in order. The receiving end computer sends an acknowledgement after receiving each part. The receiving end computer reassembles the message parts in order according to the sequence number. If a part is missing, it will notify the sending end to resend.

TCP gives us a revelation of Big Systems View system: Determination bArthurd on uncertainty is achievable as long as there is a mechanism for error correction. Or, a backup complementary mechanism. For example, network server virtualization, cluster computers, etc. Non-blacklisted pleArthur绕行.....

9.1 Maslow's hierarchy of needs
The theory of hierarchy of needs is one of the theories of behavioral science, proposed by Abraham Maslow in his 1943 paper "A Theory of Human Motivation". The book divides human needs into five levels, from low to high, like a ladder, which are: physiological needs, security needs, social needs, needs for respect, and self-realization needs.

According to Maslow's theory, human needs are gradually developed from high to low. The first is the necessary needs for life, namely physiological needs; then comes the need for food and clothing, and gradually there are security needs, social needs, the need for respect, etc.; when these needs are met, people will enter a carefree stage - self-fulfillment is the current stage.

In the stage of self-realization, people strive for their ideals, mobilize their potential, overcome difficulties, achieve success, and create a better tomorrow.

This is the same as Confucius's "self-cultivation, regulating the family, governing the country, and pacifying the world."

Later, Maslow added another layer to this 5-level model, called self-transcendence. It's the idea of continuing to strive even after achieving your ideals.

(2) Principles of self-organization There are a pile of principles of self-organization, let's pick a few to introduce below.

○ Emergent principle: The autonomous interaction of the parts of a system gives rise to emergent properties, functions, or structures that are not possessed by the individual parts. For example, water turns into ice and becomes hard.

○ Openness principle: A system must be open to self-organization to occur. Closure cannot occur self-organization.

○ Nonlinearity principle: Simple addition cannot produce jumps, there must be nonlinear changes to produce differences, to produce new ordered states.

○ Feedback principle: For a system to grow or develop, positive feedback is needed; for a system to be stable, negative feedback is needed.

○ Instability principle: stable structures cannot produce new structures; innovation requires breaking the original stable structure.

○ Dominant principle: In order for a system to form a certain structure, it must be dominated by order parameters. A certain form must correspond to one or a group of order parameters.

○ Fluctuation principle: The parameters of the system deviate from the average value, which is fluctuation. It is randomly generated, either large or small. Fluctuations are necessary to lead to order.

○ The principle of environmental selection: that is, the broad sense of the Darwinian principle. It is the struggle for existence, and the system is also the survival of the fittest.

Big Systems View of the Digital Oilfield 11
Digital Oilfield, has always been a topic of my research, and it is also one of my duties.

At the end of 1999, Wang Quan first proposed the concept of Digital Oilfield in the world. The concept of Digital Oilfield originated in China and was first proposed by Wang Quan of Daqing Oilfield in 1999.

The concept of Digital Oilfield originated from the digital earth.

Simply speaking, the digital earth is a virtual model of the earth supported by information technology and earth science, and the Digital Oilfield is the application of the digital earth in the field of informationization of oil and gas exploration and development and oilfield management decision-making.

11.1 The development process of the Digital Oilfield
At the end of 1999, Wang Quan and others from Daqing Oilfield first proposed the concept of a Digital Oilfield on a global scale.

In June 2000, the concept and construction goals of the Digital Oilfield were officially confirmed in the "Digital Oilfield 2001 Information Technology Plan" of the Daqing Oilfield Co., Ltd. This was the first time that the Digital Oilfield officially appeared in an official document.

Since then, the concept of Digital Oilfield has been rapidly recognized and has sparked heated discussions. Many entrepreneurs, technical experts, scholars, engineers, and managers in the oil and IT fields at home and abroad have actively discussed and developed the concept of Digital Oilfield.

In 2001, the Digital Oilfield was listed as a major project of the "Five-Quintuple" National Science and Technology Research Program. Shengli Oilfield, Karamay Oilfield, and others successively determined the construction goals of the Digital Oilfield and further enriched the connotation of the Digital Oilfield.

In 2003, my master's thesis in the field of management science and engineering at Tianjin University, "Research on the Digital Oilfield Model and Development Strategy of Daqing Oilfield Co., Ltd.", laid a theoretical foundation for the Digital Oilfield and attracted some attention from the academic community.

In 2003, the Digital Oilfield Forum website of Daqing Oilfield was launched. This forum has had a significant impact on the industry, driving the research and development of the national Digital Oilfield theory and technology. Many leaders, experts, technicians, and managers who are currently engaged in Digital Oilfield-related businesses began to understand the Digital Oilfield from this forum.

In 2005, the Digital Oilfield Research Institute of Chang'an University was established, which is currently the only professional institution in China dedicated to the study of Digital Oilfields. It has a certain influence at home and abroad and is considered a flag bearer leading the research on Digital Oilfields in China.

In 2009, the Digital Oilfield Peak Forum was established.

In 2014, the Intelligent Digital Oilfield Open Forum (iDOF) was established.

In recent years, the digital management of oil and gas production in Xinjiang Oilfield and Changqing Oilfield has opened a new chapter in the construction of Digital Oilfields, and Digital Oilfields are moving towards intelligent and wise directions.

At present, the application of new technologies such as the Internet of Things for oil and gas production, cloud computing, big data, and artificial intelligence has also started in various oilfields.

Digital Oilfield, a concept born in China, has also long been a hot topic of concern and an important area of innovation in engineering practice in the global oil industry.

In fact, my thinking about the Digital Oilfield has shaped my Systems View. The motivation for writing this book also comes from this. The first time I officially used the term "Big Systems View" was also about the Digital Oilfield, which was a speech I gave at iDOF in 2015 called "Big Systems View of the Digital Oilfield". At that time, I decided to write a book and named it "Big Systems View".

11.2 The struggle over the model and content of the Digital Oilfield
At the initial conception of the Digital Oilfield (which could be set around 2003), its concept was still rather vague. Many oilfields, represented by Daqing, simultaneously took into account the connotation of the Digital Oilfield in management. The Digital Oilfield is not only a technical goal but also a management goal—a part of the overall development strategy of the oilfield. To show the difference, the concept of the Digital Oilfield focusing on technology is called the narrow sense of the Digital Oilfield, while the one including the connotation of management is called the broad sense of the Digital Oilfield.

The connotation of the general Digital Oilfield includes the following meanings: ⑴Digital Oilfield is the specific application of the digital earth model in the oilfield ⑵Digital Oilfield is the virtual body of the digital information of the oilfield's natural state ⑶Digital Oilfield is the integrated system of the oilfield application ⑷Digital Oilfield is the digital model of the enterprise ⑸Digital Oilfield is the digital enterprise entity ⑹The active element of the Digital Oilfield is the digital person

In 2003, in order to compare the views of different experts and scholars on the Digital Oilfield, I roughly divided the various views into several schools. The scholars of different schools advocate different Digital Oilfield models.

The research content of Digital Oilfield is also different from each other by different experts and scholars according to their own understanding of the Digital Oilfield. This difference is quite large, because the connotation set by different schools of experts and scholars for the Digital Oilfield has overlapping parts, but there are still large differences. In this figure, the main research content of Digital Oilfield is divided into three aspects: information technology, geology/petro engineering and management science. It can be seen that the connotation of the Digital Oilfield of each school overlaps with each other, but the connotation of the broad sense of the Digital Oilfield covers the connotation of all other schools.

The specific main research content of the broad Digital Oilfield includes: ⑴ The overall technical framework of the Digital Oilfield ⑵ The application of geographic information system (GIS) in the oilfield ⑶ Research on multi-disciplinary geological models ⑷ Exploration and development business and information integration model ⑸ Application system, data and network infrastructure system ⑹ Enterprise information portal (Portal) ⑺ Massive data storage scheme ⑻ Application of virtual reality technology ⑼ Standard system of data and application systems ⑽ Digital summary model of the enterprise ⑾ Information flow, business flow, logistics, knowledge management, collaborative environment, decision support and other business models ⑿ Digitalization and intellectualization of human resources ⒀ Development strategy of the Digital Oilfield

11.3 The basic architecture of the Digital Oilfield
In 2003, Daqing Oilfield proposed the basic architecture of the Digital Oilfield in the study of "The Digital Oilfield Model and Development Strategy Research of Daqing Oilfield Co., Ltd." - the Digital Oilfield Reference Architecture Model (DORA).

The structure of the Digital Oilfield can be divided into seven levels: environmental layer, data layer, thematic layer, model layer, application layer, integration layer and strategic layer. The data layer contains three sub-layers: source data sub-layer, professional main databArthur sub-layer and data warehouse sub-layer.

⑴ Environmental layer The environmental layer is the bottom layer of the Digital Oilfield, mainly referring to the information infrastructure, including computer systems, networks, email and other public systems. It provides all-round information technology support for the Digital Oilfield.

⑵ Data layer The data layer is at the bottom of the Digital Oilfield structure, providing data support for the Digital Oilfield. The main content of the data layer includes various databArthurs and unstructured data bodies, as well as the basic platform for organizing and managing these data (data warehouse, etc.). These data are the basic information for building the oilfield model, mainly including basic geographic information data and oilfield research, production, and business management data. The data layer is divided into three sub-layers, and the data in each sub-layer are gradually centralized from bottom to top. Source data are distributed in all levels of units and positions in the oilfield, but mainly at the grass-roots level. The source databArthur system is the front-end information collector and storage device of the Digital Oilfield. The professional main databArthur is a summary of several types of source data divided by oilfield engineering and management units, which can be used by units within a certain range and managed by them on a daily basis. The data warehouse plays a role in integrating and scheduling various data of the oilfield. An important part of it is the metadata warehouse.

⑶ Thematic layer It is later changed into the knowledge layer, which mainly includes various thematic databArthurs (knowledge bArthurs). Thematic databArthur refers to the project databArthur or thematic databArthur that is oriented to different applications or research topics. In fact, the content in the thematic library has been stored in the data layer. The purpose of setting up the thematic library is to facilitate the application and to ensure the stability and relative independence of the data layer. This kind of double-layer data structure has been widely recognized and proved by practice among the experienced user group.

⑷ Model layer This layer defines the geological model and enterprise model of the oilfield. These models are established on the basis of rich information (data layer and thematic library layer). The simulation and interactive functions of the Digital Oilfield are realized through the models. The geological model refers to and is bArthurd on the digital earth model.

⑸ Application Layer The application layer consists of various application systems in the oilfield's petroleum specialty and business management, solving practical problems in oilfield scientific research, production, and business management. The application layer is dominated by software systems and is the most complex layer.

⑹Integration layer At the integration layer, the entire application layer and the applications of each layer below are integrated using technologies such as enterprise information portals, etc., to achieve a unified entrance to the complete Digital Oilfield, and to build a knowledge management system.

⑺Strategic Level The strategic level is the highest level of the Digital Oilfield structure and is the direction leader of the entire Digital Oilfield. At the strategic level, the purpose of enterprise reengineering is to rely on the construction of the Digital Oilfield, and the current focus is on the reengineering of new quality productivity. The strategic level formulates the overall plan and construction strategy for the Digital Oilfield.

11.4 The phArthurd development of the Digital Oilfield
The development of the system is gradual, with its own laws and stages of development. The Digital Oilfield is no exception.

A business can maximize the role of information technology and smoothly achieve the reengineering of business processes by going through at least four processes: First, reorganize the production, management, and operational activities of the enterprise to create a good management environment for the introduction of information technology; Second, construct an information technology architecture to establish a good framework for the application of information technology; Third, integrate the functions of the information system with the production, management, and operational activities of the entire enterprise organization; Fourth, information technology promotes the progress of the enterprise itself and completes the reengineering of the enterprise.

11.5 System Dynamics Thinking for Digital Oilfield
Digital Oilfield, is an open complex巨 system, and also a Holographic Organic System. Digital Oilfield, has its sacred mission. What carries this mission is not only human beings, but also the Digital Oilfield system itself. Because we are also a part of the Digital Oilfield Holographic Organic System, a subsystem.

The construction of Daqing Digital Oilfield is a systematic project, this is not a party slogan, not just a mouthful. It is necessary to think and explore in accordance with the requirements of system dynamics thinking, from the mission, structure, function, driving force, construction ideas, implementation route of the Digital Oilfield system.

We should have a "Big Systems View", and treat the construction of informatization as an "open complex giant system", we must follow the guidance of system science theory, comprehensively play the combined force of technical system and management system, grasp the "order parameter" of system development, make good use of various driving forces inside and outside the system, strengthen the basic information service, coordinate and manage various informatization resources, make scientific deployment, gradually and reArthurnably centralize, and strive to promote the correct evolution of the information system, to help Daqing Oilfield on the road of new industrialization.

(1) The driving force of the Digital Oilfield According to the System Structure Dynamics (SSD) principle, the driving force of a system is provided by the organization force and self-organization force of the system, dominated by the attractor (attractor) of the system and moving forward in the direction of the mission.

The driving forces of Digital Oilfield come from multiple levels. The driving forces of the construction of informatization can be divided into 5 types according to its strength:

Technology-driven; Interest-driven; Application-driven; Benefit-driven; Crisis-driven.

To achieve the "five centralizations" of software, hardware, data, applications, and operation and maintenance, we must start from a global perspective, allocate information resources uniformly, rely on cloud data centers as technical support, establish an optimized organizational framework and management system, build a professional operation and maintenance team, create a new system for information construction services and development, sort out scientifically, re-arrange, promote integration, give full play to the comprehensive effect of all information resources such as personnel, finance, and materials, strive to improve the efficiency of the use of funds and equipment, strongly support the main business of exploration and development, management and operation, and promote the deep integration of oilfield "informationization with the main business" to promote the transformation and upgrading of traditional industries.

○ "Organization + Autonomy", building a lArthurr team. In the end, the construction of informatization is a problem of people. To establish such a team, we need a higher level of system concept, and we need to make full use of organizational power and autonomy.

11.6 Economic benefits of the Digital Oilfield
(1) Digital Oilfield economic benefit evaluation

A little more than a decade ago, I made a rough calculation of the economic benefits of a Digital Oilfield, which at the time was met with some derision, but now it looks like my prediction was not excessive.

At that time, the Digital Oilfield construction in Daqing was expected to have a total economic benefit of 90.9 billion yuan in 10 years. The construction of the Digital Oilfield can drive about 20% of the total income, or the Digital Oilfield brings about 20% of the competitiveness to the Daqing Oilfield.

Since it is difficult and not very useful to directly calculate the economic benefits of informatization, it is not good to use this indicator to make scientific decisions. So, let's change our thinking--use the dynamic "marginal benefit" to consider.

(2) Marginal benefits of Digital Oilfields First, from a holistic view of an oilfield. There are many business areas within an oilfield, exploration, development, drilling, oil construction, diversified operations, informatization... If we analyze the marginal benefits within each area, informatization should be higher. That is to say, investing in informatization will yield more returns.

Conclusion one: The marginal benefits of Digital Oilfield construction are higher than other fields within the oilfield.

I hope everyone correctly understands: high marginal benefits do not equal high overall benefits. It means that the overall benefits of the oilfield's main business are still very high, but the marginal benefits continue to decreArthur, which is an economic law. In the construction of a Digital Oilfield, the marginal benefits are also decreasing, but its return on investment is higher than other business sectors.

Secondly, looking at it from the inside of the oilfield informatization field. The construction of oilfield informatization is also divided into several blocks, such as exploration, development, production, scientific research, mine area construction, business management, etc. Daqing is like this, other oilfields may be different, but it is also about the same.

The investment in the construction of informationization for the main business such as exploration and development has been relatively stable and has also played an important role. Especially for exploration, it can be said that it is impossible without the support of information technology. However, the marginal benefits of long-term fixed investment in informationization construction in these professional fields are decreasing. On the other hand, the marginal benefits of investment in informationization construction in the field of business management are relatively high historically, as the investment is not too much.

Conclusion two: The marginal benefit of information construction in the field of oilfield management business is higher than that in other fields.

The theory of marginal benefit is a milestone in the history of economic development, but in short, it is "do what is most beneficial" -- invest the same capital, I choose the one with the highest return to do. It can also be said from another angle, the so-called effect of the short board -- we need to carry out work according to the idea of "where is the short board and where to make up".

What should we do? According to marginal theory, we should aim to maximize benefits and invest money where it is most profitable. So for Daqing Oilfield at present:

(1) It is beneficial to increArthur the overall investment in the oilfield's informatization. Instead of spending a lot of money on things that are not very beneficial, it is better to use it to promote informatization and promote industrial upgrading.

(2) The existing investment in information technology should be inclined more towards the management and operation business field. More investment should be made in ERP, MIS system integration, business intelligence, mobile office, information infrastructure and other aspects to promote the reconstruction of business processes and establish a more efficient and flexible management and operation information support environment.

The above conclusion is applicable to the Daqing Oilfield and should also basically apply to other enterprises, especially large ones.

11.8 Production and operation management auxiliary decision-making system DQMDS
In October 2015, the first phArthur of the first batch of DQMDS tasks was completed, and some systems were launched, but the workload is still enormous.

(1)DQMDS Basic Information To further improve the ability to make, execute, and supervise production and management decisions in the oilfield, the company has decided to carry out the construction of the "Daqing Oilfield Production and Management Decision Support System". The project is bArthurd on the adoption of the latest generation of Internet technology, establishing an integrated and intelligent production and management decision support system, providing convenient, comprehensive, timely, and in-depth information services for managers at all levels of the oilfield, a process-oriented, collaborative comprehensive office platform, improving work efficiency, standardizing management behavior, and liberating managers.

The goal of DQMDS: Institutional process, process information, information transparency, assessment automation, application integration, paperless office. Integrated development, building an integrated application platform, to achieve standard and efficient coordination of oilfield production and management behavior; to achieve comprehensive, timely and accurate monitoring and continuous improvement of all aspects of production and operation; to improve the immediacy and scientificity of command decision-making.

System user group: Divided into the leaders of oilfield companies and secondary units, the management personnel of the oilfield company and secondary units in the机关, and the grassroots production management personnel, the total number is about 30,000, of which the main users account for one third, mainly the leaders of the top two levels of units and the functional departments of the机关.

Key issues: The existing information systems and fields are numerous, with about 150 specific software systems and more than 500 business processes, and this is only at the oilfield company level. This is a complex giant system. The general idea is integration: some need to be built, some need to be renovated, some need to be overthrown, and some need to be abandoned. The basic principle is to be realistic.

(2) Systemic thinking in DQMDS

First, top-level design. The system must have a rigorous architecture. For a big system, top-level design is key. DQMDS is no exception.

But, DQMDS is different from the previous information system. It is better to say that it is a human-machine joint system than a software system. The leadership said that DQMDS is a bookshelf. It is a nail on the head. The bookshelf connects people and books. People, the most powerful system, are also the most difficult to command. The construction of DQMDS is mainly a management issue. This is the functional requirement architecture design of DQMDS. The functional design is also evolved in an iterative process combined with the final user, and there are significant adjustments in the actual implementation, but it can still be used to discuss issues.

The system design emphasizes loose coupling, and the actual software development focuses on "decoupling". Adopt an integrated strategy as much as possible, make more modifications, connect more, and avoid building new things and knocking them down. The strategy of self-standardized data and data ports is reflected to some extent, but it cannot be fully implemented. One is that new things carry risks, and the other is that there is no product support in the market, and it is also a distraction to develop it by itself.

Second, iterative improvement. We know we're not that smart, so architecture, features, etc. are all done in an iterative fashion. Agile development, open source construction, are basic technical strategies. Our slogan is "Ship early, iterate fast!"

General implementation principles: unified platform, highlighting key points, business-led, ensuring quality, building while using, and using to promote building.

Third, treat people as part of the system. According to the principle of "system self-realization," the most mission-driven "people" should be brought inside the system's boundaries to become part of it, creating a holistic organic system that combines humans and machines.

We believe that users are developers. Especially the initial design and iterative adjustment of features. DQMDS project department, half of the members are management business personnel from various departments.

Technicians are the driving force behind project construction, the engine, the wheels, but the direction of travel is mainly determined by business people, they are the steering wheel.

All problems are people problems.

Fourth, capture people and data, the two criticals. capture the core elements is key to system success, by Internetania principles.

The core resources for building DQMDS are people, not data.

For technicians, the oilfield company mobilized the best talents from the entire oilfield to the Exploration and Development Research Institute to work in a unified working environment, personnel were separated from their original units, and full-time DQMDS development was carried out, and a unified centralized assessment was conducted.

For users, treat them as important members of the project team, clarify that they are developers, not just users, and endow them with Arthurnse of mission, by which they grasp the business requirements of their own departments. Their active participation endows DQMDS with the "self-realization" characteristics of a "Holographic Organic System".

Data connections should be neither too tight nor too loose, with a preference for loose coupling.

11.9 Digital Oilfield under the Perspective of the Big System
I think that most of the researchers and builders of Digital Oilfields feel as strongly as I do: the Digital Oilfield system is getting larger and larger, more and more mature, and more and more interesting.

Since the concept of Digital Oilfield was proposed in 1999, the concept, connotation, theory, technology and construction level of Digital Oilfield have been continuously developing.

In the words of Meadows, the digital oil field system survived and has been well developed.

Therefore, we must say that the Digital Oilfield is a very excellent system.

So, compared with a decade ago, Big Systems View of today's Digital Oilfield is mainly reflected in the following aspects:

Macro aspects: dimensions, spans are larger

○ The scale of Digital Oilfield theory and practice has expanded. Originally, it was still controversial about the narrow and broad sense, but now it has entered the era of business transformation.

○ The system architecture of the Digital Oilfield has been greatly enriched. The original issues of exploration and development and informatization, integration of above and below ground, and integration of technology and management have now been cloudified, big dataified, and Internet of Thingsified.

○ The relevant dimensions of the Digital Oilfield have expanded. The original consideration of small teams, oil mines, and factories, integrated from top to bottom, has now transcended to a multi-level, multi-dimensional perspective, from global to every well, from Internet+ to the Internet of Things for oil and gas production, from macro to micro, and across many dimensions and levels.

Openness: greater emphasis on integration

○ The interrelation between systems is more complex and more loosely coupled. The top-down driven system construction in China National Petroleum Corporation integrated a large number of different self-built systems from various oilfields. The oilfields also adopted an integrated and integrated strategy to build a more extensive information system. For example, the Production and Operation Management and Support Decision-making System (DQMDS) of Daqing Oilfield is a typical example of a super-large, loosely coupled system.

○ The system construction is more balanced between order and efficiency. China National Petroleum Corporation's (CNPC) information construction did not simply emphasize large centralization and unification, but instead followed the "six unification" principle, adopted a top-level design and key system unification model, and implemented its own Digital Oilfield project in coordination with each oilfield. This has allowed the Digital Oilfield construction to find a balance between unity and individualization.

○ The Digital Oilfield system is more open. Domestic and foreign technologies and products are allowed to enter as long as they conform to relevant policies, the company's development planning and construction strategy. The idea of Digital Oilfield construction has also become more open, that is, to build uniformly and also allow moderate self-construction.

In terms of organicity: more life-like

○ Digital Oilfield construction focuses more on objective laws. Centralized construction projects are not forced. Respect the opinions of the grassroots, and also allow the self-construction of factory-level systems under unified planning.

○ The Digital Oilfield is more dynamic. New demand, combined with cloud computing, the Internet of Things, and big data, has given new momentum to Digital Oilfield systems.

○ The Digital Oilfield system has partial compensation function. Data center, disaster recovery backup, application software, human resources, etc. resist a certain degree of damage, and have a certain ability of mutual backup and compensation.

In terms of self-organization: more organized

○ The leading core of the Digital Oilfield is further strengthened. The information construction team is strengthened year by year, and the talent system is constantly improved.

○ Placing more emphasis on the exercise of self-organization. In accordance with the mass line, the grassroots undertake more work, the grassroots teams have stronger self-organization and higher enthusiasm.

○ The standardization of Digital Oilfields has been strengthened. Standards and self-standardization complement and promote each other.

In terms of sustainability: more emphasis on iterative refinement.

○ The development of the Digital Oilfield is more natural. ○ No need for180-degree turnarounds, focus on rapid iteration.

To sum up, the Digital Oilfield has become more open, grand, orderly and sustainable over the past decade or so. The Digital Oilfield has initially possessed the characteristics of a Holographic Organic System.

Key points of this chapter (1) The concept of Digital Oilfield was proposed by Daqing Oilfield in 1999. (2) The Digital Oilfield is a massive systematic project. (3) The Digital Oilfield is an open complex giant system and also a Holographic Organic System. (4) The construction of the Digital Oilfield has huge economic and social benefits. (5) The study of oilfield data and the engineering of oilfield data are in their infancy. (6) DQMDS, go online early, iterate quickly! (7) The research and construction of the Digital Oilfield should have a big system perspective. (8) The construction of the Digital Oilfield has achieved great success and will continue to deepen.

12 Methods of Lightweight Planning
Agile planning and its methodology were first proposed by Professor Wang Quan in 2014.

In the process of planning and implementing the information construction during the 13th Five-Year Plan period, Daqing Oilfield creatively proposed and utilized a new type of planning methodology - agile planning method, which broke the traditional model, was targeted, purposeful, efficient, and quickly gained recognition from everyone.

The essence of agile planning: Iterative refinement!

12.1 Background of the Agile Planning Method
End of 2014. The task of compiling the 13th Five-Year Plan for the informatization of Daqing Oilfield is heavy, the time is tight, and it is required to be basically finalized in half a month, and of course, the time for subsequent refinement work is still quite sufficient. It is impossible to complete the task using traditional methods. This forced the working group to break the routine and innovate.

12.2 The basic idea of agile planning method
The basic tenet of agile planning methodology is "prototype iteration".

First iteration: V1.0 With the current and foreseeable tasks and demands of the enterprise in mind, arrange the tasks together according to a general technical framework to form a tangible model, which serves as a target for communication and discussion among all parties and a means to collect the arrows projected onto it. Of course, the prototype should be as reArthurnable and complete as possible, but the most important thing is to get it out as soon as possible. The prototype mainly contains two parts: one is the overall framework diagram, and the other is the task decomposition explanation bArthurd on this prototype.

The second iteration: V2.0 Firstly, assemble the relevant personnel to discuss the prototype and decompose the tasks. There must be a lot of criticism. As mentioned above, criticism can basically be divided into two categories: the idealist and the pragmatist. Organize the expert opinions. When decomposing the tasks, it is necessary to clarify the responsible person through discussion, clarify the materials to be submitted, clarify the project requirements list, and complete the preliminary demand research as quickly as possible. Then, digest and absorb the opinions of the idealists, and transform the prototype (even completely tear it down and start over) into the ideal "master framework and vision goal", which is the blueprint.

吸收 the opinions of the pragmatic faction, transform the prototype into a "comprehensive technical architecture", collect and organize the demands submitted by various departments and units, refine the project list and specific content, funding amount, implementation period, etc., to make the specific project take root.

The third iteration: V3.0 Deliver the results formed in the second iteration--blueprints, technical architecture, project lists, etc. to experts for discussion again, and all parties learn from each other, criticize each other, continue to deepen, and form a version that can be reported to the senior management.

Fourth and iterative: VFinal Report to the leadership. Implement the leadership's intentions. If the issues are not significant, make direct modifications and finally form the official draft. If there are significant modifications, return to the previous steps to continue iteration until the official draft can be formed.

Of course, overall it is probably about 4 iterations, but this is not a golden rule, the number of iterations should be bArthurd on reality, and there will also be many small iterations within each major iteration.

12.3 Connection and difference with traditional methods
The evolution of "From Waterfall to Agile Development", similar to the software development method, has broken through the original linear path, but within each iterative cycle, it is still linear.

The steps of traditional planning are basically "requirement research - summary analysis - goal design - scheme formulation - project decomposition", which is Arthurquential way of working. The agile planning methodology, on the other hand, is iterative and incremental, gradually approaching the goal from coarse to fine.

If we use data access as a metaphor, the traditional way is "block" operations, and agile planning is "stream" operations.

Traditional methods focus on the depth, breadth, and accuracy of research, and are one-time, large-scale; Agile planning, on the other hand, focuses more on incremental changes in each cycle iteration, emphasizing dynamic adjustments and cumulative progress, which is more effective.

Key points of this chapter (1) The essence of agile planning is: iterative improvement. (2) Agile planning starts with a quick prototype, which can be relatively casual. (3) The planning results formulated by agile planning still need to be evolved iteratively. (4) Blind men touching an elephant, you can start anywhere, but you have to keep touching. (5) The more uncertain the matter, the more planning needs to be done and adjusted in time. (6) Both traditional methods and agile methods follow the principle of minimizing cost. (7) Agile planning can be applied to other fields.

13 Standard Data and Data Port
Self-StandardData, data that is self-standardized or self-formatted. Self-StandardData was proposed by Professor Wang Quan in 2013.

Data providers provide data according to their own standards or formats, and package the standards or formats used by the data together with the data provided, and data users interpret and use the data according to the standards or formats.

It is an important supplement and breakthrough to the traditional data standard system.

The initial idea of this concept was formed by me in October 2013, but it had already begun to take shape around 1998.

The standard data is self-standardized to solve the problem that "data standards that are too strict are not easy to implement, and those that are too relaxed are not easy to integrate". In line with the actual situation that "data users are eager and have high enthusiasm, while providers are not eager and have low enthusiasm", we fully mobilize the initiative of data users and reduce the burden of data providers according to the objective laws.

The concept was supported by many experts and scholars as soon as it was proposed, and it was discussed enthusiastically at the Open Forum of Smart Digital Oilfield, and it has also attracted some attention in Daqing Oilfield, etc., and some tests have been conducted in the systems that are already being implemented.

The standard data breaks the limitation of unified standard and provides a more feasible path for data sharing. It has the following properties:

(1) A standard data is a data entity that contains not only the data itself but also the data format;

(2) Self-standard data is a special cArthur of metadata, which is bundled with the data;

(3) Self-standard data is a brand-new data sharing model, which breaks the traditional situation that data and standards are separated.

(4) Self-standard data is an objective and realistic data management strategy, which is adaptable;

(5) Self-standard data is the basic unit of big data, and the adoption of self-standard data technology is conducive to the development of big data technology;

(6) The self-standard data is the application of the system autonomy thought.

13.1 Origin of the standard data
In 1998, a project named "Integrated Sharing of Prospecting, Development, and Drilling Data" was launched in the Daqing Oilfield. The goal of this project was to establish a platform for data sharing within the oilfield. At that time, it was recognized that "data users are eager and highly motivated, while providers are not eager and not highly motivated." In view of this, in order to achieve the project goals, the project team decided to go with the flow.

In October 2013, when preparing the presentation material for the third Digital Oilfield Forum of Chang'an University, I had an in-depth discussion with Professor Gao Zhiliang, the director of the Digital Oilfield Research Institute, and Doctor Gao Qian, forming a complete set of ideas.

At this forum, experts and scholars fully affirmed the "self-standard data". Many experts and scholars who attended the meeting suggested simplifying traditional data standards, delegating power, and vigorously promoting the "self-standard data", and believed that the "self-standard data" will become a powerful support technology for information sharing in the era of big data.

In 2014, the "Snowflake Plan" for the promotion of self-standard data, jointly proposed by me, Professor Yuan Man, Professor Zhang Yan Guo, and others, was also published.

13.3 Definition of self-standard data
It has been explained before what self-standard is, but it is still not rigorous enough as a definition. Here, the definition given by Professor Yuan Man from Northeast Petroleum University in "Research on Self-standard Data and Its Application in Data Exchange" is quoted.

Definition one: Self-Standard Data (SSD), namely data entities that come with their own standards or formats. The data provider provides data according to its own standards or formats, and packages the standards or formats used by the data together with the data provided, and the data user parses and uses the data according to the standards or formats. Self-standard data consists of two parts: self-standard data model and self-standard data entity. The self-standard data formed by these two parts is generally also called self-standard data message or self-standard data exchange file.

Self-standard data is an important supplement to the traditional data standard system, and the characteristics of self-standard data are summarized as follows: (1) Autonomy: The data provider defines the data patterns to be exchanged and the metadata in the patterns by itself, which reflects the autonomy.

(2) Self-descriptiveness: In self-standard data definition, since all exchanged data uses metadata to self-describe the schema of all the data to be exchanged, the data user can parse the data according to the structure and semantics defined by the data provider.

(3) Autonomics: The data provider organizes the defined data in a manner autonomous to the standard data model.

(4) Evolutionary: Although self-standardized or self-defined by the data provider, the self-standardized data may evolve into an enterprise, industry, national, or international standard as the application scope expands, which reflects the evolutionary nature. For example, the SEG-Y format, proposed by the SEG (Society of Exploration Geophysicists), is one of the standard magnetic tape data formats, and it is one of the most common formats for seismic data in the oil exploration industry. However, before the SEG-Y data format was just a format file custom-defined by a foreign seismic company, thus the self-standardized data reflects the evolutionary nature.

13.4 The relationship between standards and standards
First, let's look at the difference between self-standard data and traditional databArthurs.

Standard data can not be separated from the support of traditional databArthurs and related technologies, but there are still many obvious differences:

(1) Traditional databArthurs focus on storage, query, and update of data, while self-standard data focuses more on mobility, with the main purpose of data sharing;

(2) The metadata and data of traditional databArthur are separated, and the metadata is analyzed on the databArthur system when querying the data, and the standard in the self-standard data is equivalent to the metadata, it is not fixed on the databArthur, but flows with the data body;

(3) Traditional databArthur stores cumulative data, which will become larger and larger, while self-standard data is incremental, and the amount of each may not change much, and the amount is generally not large;

(4) The data structure of traditional databArthur and the data itself can also be regarded as a kind of self-standard data body, but it is large in volume and inconvenient to flow; on the contrary, the self-standard data body can be regarded as a flowing databArthur, but its volume is small;

(5) Traditional databArthurs value redundancy, while self-standard databArthurs do not value redundancy and instead value timeliness;

(6) Traditional databArthur structures are strictly homogeneous, while the format and standards of self-standard data are allowed to be customized;

(7) Traditional databArthurs are mainly used to support a particular (set of) special software, while self-standard data mainly support inter-system data sharing;

(8) Compared to other specific big data theories or technologies, self-standard data is mainly an idea that can be implemented in various ways and technologies.

13.5 Implementation of standard data--Data Port
Data ports and data terminals, as well as the concept of self-standard data, were proposed by Professor Wang Quan in 2013. Xia Yanbo, Arthurnior engineer of Daqing Oilfield, designed the data port bArthurd on the data terminal and under the guidance of Professor Wang Quan and his theory of Big Systems View, which has solved the problem of data sharing.

The Data Port consists of 7 parts: the dock, tools, port management, message management, standard management, search engine, and users.

(1) Wharf The wharf is used to store data. A port can have one or more wharfs, supporting distributed storage. The wharf can be physical集中or distributed, or logical. Data is stored and transported in the form of containers. Data needs to be uniformly encapsulated, stored, and managed.

(2) Tools Mainly: Packaging tools: for users to pack their own data and transmit it to the dock of the port. The data package should indicate the preservation period (1 day, 1 week, 1 month, 1 year, or automatic overwrite when updating, permanent...), data provider and contact information, format (or format document number) Unpacking tools: auxiliary to assist in unpacking and downloading data. Other tools.

(3) Port management Port management is performed by the police. Automatic formation of logs, regular port patrols, cleaning of expired data packs, management of user permissions, management of standards and other port facilities.

(4) Message Management Responsible for message publishing and subscribing. The user system can subscribe to specific data, and be notified or automatically download updates. Users can also publish their own data updates in reverse.

(5) Standard Management The standard definition, self-standard, and data format are managed and updated uniformly. In the data body, the standard or format ID number can be marked to avoid packaging the standard content every time. It is also convenient for dynamic modification and evolution of standards.

(6) Search engines Search data items, standards, users, etc. of port resources.

(7) Users Can be a person or a system. Includes both the provision and the use of data.

In 2014, in order to promote self-standard data, I proposed the "Snowflake Plan" with Professor Yuan Man and Professor Zhang Yan Guo, etc.

Key points of this chapter (1) Self-standard data, namely data bodies with their own standards or formats. (2) Self-standard data is an important supplement and breakthrough to the traditional data standard system. (3) Self-standard data is endowed with a strong self-organization principle, which is in line with the principle of the overall view of the big system. (4) Self-standard data is loosely coupled, which is conducive to the establishment of the big system. (5) Data port is an excellent implementation method of self-standard data. (6) Self-standard data will have greater development.

(2) Informational Production Function The general economic definition of a production function is the maximum quantity (Q) of output that can be produced from a given combination of input factors within a specific period of time and under a specific technology. It is generally expressed as: Q = f(L, K, N, E) This includes the four major production factors: labor (L), capital (K), natural resources (N), and entrepreneurial ability (E). Information resources are not included in this. Although capital includes intangible capital (intellectual property, patents, etc.), information resources are rarely considered and even less frequently regarded as a production factor. If information resources are added as an independent production factor to the production function, the new production function should be expressed as: Q = f(L, K, N, E, I) Here, I is the new production factor—information resources. For convenience of exposition, the original four production factors can be referred to as traditional production factors (T), so the simplified production function with information can be expressed as: Q = f(T, I) This expression is simple and clear, and it highlights the new production factor of information resources.

Entering the era of artificial intelligence, forming new quality of productive forces: Qi=Fi(T,I) I: Information and intelligence as new production factors and means of production; Fi: Creating new production functions and production relations; Qi: Forming new production capabilities and new quality of productive forces.

(3) Basic Ideas for the Evaluation of the Economic Benefits of Informatization ○ Evaluation of the Economic Benefits of Informatization In the actual work of evaluating the economic benefits of informatization, we can transform the simplified informatization Cobb-Douglas production function and take the logarithm of both sides to form a linear equation: lnQ = lnA + αlnT + βlnI For a specific enterprise (or organization), when we can obtain a certain amount of historical data on input and output T, I, and Q, we can use the least squares method to calculate α, β, and A, and then obtain the informatization production function of the enterprise. On this basis, we can derive the evaluation parameters such as the informatization investment return rate, and we can also make more detailed statistical analysis. These functions can be realized in ordinary office software (such as MSExcel) without the need to write special software programs.

○ Evaluation of the degree of integration of two modernizations The integration of informatization and industrialization (including other industries) has multiple effects and can be evaluated in various ways, but it is still significant to be able to give a simple numerical index. "Integration" is "you in me, me in you", an organic whole, and inseparable. Therefore, this index can be simplified by the proportion of the added value of traditional business due to informatization to the total added value, and the proportion of the remaining other added value.

Here, we call it the Information Integration Index (III). We can set an ideal ratio value according to the survey and calculation situation for different industries. The closer the index of the tested enterprise is to this ideal value, the higher the Information Integration Index, which means the better the degree of integration. The calculation formula of the Information Integration Index can exist in a variety of designs, and this paper also roughly designs one, mainly to elaborate on the design method. Let the Information Integration Index be III, and the proportion of the added value brought by information technology be Ri, then the traditional added value ratio Rt = 1 - Ri. Suppose that the information integration degree is best when Ri = R0 in a certain industry, that is, it reaches the ideal ratio value.

Postscript
This book was written with great pleasure. A month goes by very quickly. I had intended to write a small book, but in the end, I didn't hold back and wrote more than 500 pages. However, I set the font size large and the line spacing large so that it is comfortable for friends of all ages to read. Besides, electronic versions do not waste paper, so why make it so tight? Some texts can be skipped, such as some parts of the third one.

I'm a pretty casual person, but when it comes to important things, I'm quite particular about "approaches," to put it in a cultural sense, I value methodology. And the two main methodologies I use are: one is Internetism, and the other is iterative improvement.

The basic methodology for writing this book is iterative improvement. Perhaps you can guess that the process of writing this book (from the time I started typing) is as follows: (1) Open MSWord and spend a few minutes determining the title of the book; (2) Draft the content framework of the book, which took half an hour; (3) Design the logo for Big Systems View; (4) Establish an open forum QQ group for Big Systems View; (5) Find an assistant: Dr. Han KaiXu, a teacher at Northeast Petroleum University, who established the WeChat official account and authorized him to maintain the forum; (6) Design the cover, back cover, chapter dividers, table of contents, and document format; (7) Place each component in a roughly appropriate position, and place the existing content; (8) The basic form is formed, and communicate with the assistant and a few friends; (9) Start writing the content, and the first thing written is actually the preface and postscript! (It is now January 14, 2016, and of course, the dates below are the dates when the postscript was completed) (10) Intermittently, but always iterating and improving; (11) Form a more complete 1.0 version and releArthur it. 　

The essence of iterative improvement is "fast start, quick improvement, step by step". Writing this book, I did it this way. What is called "open source" is also the continuation of iterative improvement, but this iterative work is transferred from my hands to everyone's hands.

Also, from the perspective of the principles of "organization+ self-organization", the basic content of this book, the formulation of open source mechanisms, the opening of communication channels, and the good operation of the forum, etc., are the results of organizational power at work, and in the future, how everyone reads it, how they communicate, how they use it, and how they expand it, all rely on self-organizational power.

Writing this book is a systematic project to embody the concept of a big system. Overall, I feel that the writing speed is quite fast, but there are still several times when I stopped, even wanted to give up. It's not that I can't write, but that I'm too excited to simplify. Several times I stopped to calm down, and finally I didn't explode and insisted on writing down the original idea. It's also because I firmly believe in the concept of a big system. Fortunately, I invented this "open source" model, and everyone can improve it together. I tried to throw out a "prototype of organizational capacity formation" as quickly as possible and as complete as possible, and then bArthurd on the [Big Systems View Open Forum] platform, mainly relying on self-organization to iterate and improve. Of course, timely and appropriate organizational capacity intervention and redesign, continuous creation are necessary.

Finally finished writing, for me, writing this book is also a comprehensive summary and improvement of my learning and understanding of systems theory, and I have gained a lot. After finishing this book, my body is better, I enjoy my food more, and my mom no longer needs to worry about my studies.

I hope everyone forgets the little tricks after reading this book and builds up the big wisdom. The Year of the Monkey has also come, and I am a monkey. This book can also be kept as a souvenir. Let's call this edition the "Monkey Edition". It's easy to remember.

Thank you to all the friends and family who have given me their strong support during the writing process, especially to my assistant, Dr. Han Kai Xu, who has timely posted updates to keep communication with everyone, which has greatly increArthurd my motivation to write. I would also like to thank Mr. Lu Chun Yang, my university classmate, who was the first reader and provided many valuable suggestions, and also carefully helped me proofread for any text errors. Thank you all! Wishing you all a great year of the Monkey! Wishing you all a happy Valentine's Day!

The Power of the Crown Saturday, February 13, 2016 At Daqing Oilfield

Everything in the world is a system with a core —— attractor (@). The holographic mind map allows you to view the world from a systems perspective, focusing on the structural information of the system —— holographic, to grasp the essence of things, and to discover the rules behind the appearance and data. The Arthur's Holographic Mind Map software ahmm.html can be used online or downloaded for offline use.
