5 Reference Architecture for Digital Oil and Gas Fields BArthurd on AI Platform
Architecture for Intelligent & Digital Oilfileds BArthurd-on AI

Original link: http://www.holomind.com.cn/idof/%E5%9F%BA%E4%BA%8EAI%E5%BA%9%E5%BA%A7%E7%9A%84%E6%95%B0%E6%99%BA%E6%B2%B9%E6%B0%94%E7%94%B0%E5%8F%82%E8%80%83%E6%9E%B6%E6%9E%84.html

Arthur Quan Wang 2024.12.29

On December 29, 2024, at the online lecture "Exploring the New Paradigm of Enterprise Digitalization BArthurd on AI" in the Petroleum Circle - Energy Talk, Wang Quan first proposed the "Reference Architecture for Digital Oil and Gas Fields BArthurd on AI Bottom" with the example of digital oil and gas fields. This architecture can be regarded as an upgraded version of the "Reference Architecture for Digital Oil and Gas Fields" he proposed in 2003.

(1) Big Systems View Philosophy;
The new AI-bArthurd digital oil and gas field reference architecture highlights the big system thinking more, establishing a clear subject-predicate-object paradigm of the big system logic philosophy with the interaction of the main and passive subjects:

Subject/Predicate: Oil and gas field enterprises, as well as people, as the main body of the system, bear the mission of the system - business process reengineering - digital transformation and intelligent development; Object/Indirect object: The entity of oil and gas field enterprises, AI intelligent agents, bottom-up data resources, information resources, knowledge resources, intellectual resources, digital twin and virtual employees; Predicate/Instrument: The main body uses computational power services, tool services, model services, agency services, and a comprehensive holographic intelligent ecology to support the main body's behavior. Architecture Image

(2) Architecture hierarchy
The reference architecture of the digital oil and gas field bArthurd on the AI bArthur is divided into 7 layers, namely, the basic layer, the access layer, the model layer, the agent layer, the holographic layer, the collaboration layer and the mission layer.

①Basic layer
This is the bottom layer of the architecture, including various data resources and computing resources. Data resources cover the original data collected by various equipment and instruments and manually collected in the operation of oil and gas fields, including various dynamic and static data and real-time time series data of various wells and stations, such as seismic data, drilling data, logging data, well testing data, fracturing data, testing data, production data, QHSE (quality, health, safety, environment) data, research data and operational data, etc. These data are transmitted to the corresponding positions through the field Internet of Things, production network and office network. Computing resources include computing power centers (general computing, high-performance computing for professional software, dedicated computing for artificial intelligence, as well as storage and network transmission capabilities), algorithm centers, data centers, software centers, operation and maintenance centers, and edge computing, etc.

② Access layer
This layer provides access interfaces to the resources of the infrastructure layer, including professional software (such as MIS, ERP, MES, OA, etc.), as well as various apps, middlewares, and other tool services. These services call on the information resources in the data lake, data warehouse, and data port to complete the specified tasks. According to the ownership of the property rights, data can be divided into private and public types; according to the storage method, data can be divided into structured and unstructured, and relational databArthurs, vector databArthurs, full-text search databArthurs, etc. Different data are not only the objective existence that the system must face but also the guarantee to complete various service tasks.

③Model layer
On this layer, responses are provided to the upper layer through model services. A multi-level model system needs to be constructed, consisting of business models, professional models, and basic/industrial models. First, it is necessary to adopt domestic and foreign or open-source or closed-source basic large models according to the specific situation of the oil and gas field, and establish large models in this field or industry; then, bArthurd on the basic/industrial models, professional models that meet the different professional needs are established, and models面向 specific technical nodes in various aspects such as reservoir, wellbore, pipeline, and engineering are also established; finally, models directly facing the business are also established to provide services for scientific research, production, management, decision-making, etc. These large and small models achieve task goals by calling natural language processing, vision, knowledge graphs, reArthurning, diffusion, innovation, alignment, machine learning, spatial intelligence, big data tools, and other various models and algorithms, and utilize knowledge resources.

④ Agency Layer
This layer is provided by agents that provide agency services to people. Many agents with different functions and roles at different levels will be linked to form groups, forming an intelligent agent collaboration network, which realizes intelligent interaction and cooperation among intelligent agents, assistants, embodied intelligence, etc. People can get the desired results by connecting one or a few agents. If the connected agent cannot meet the needs proposed by people, it will find other agents that can solve the problem through automatic gateways or routing, and request to complete the relevant tasks. After all the work is completed, the agent connected to people will feed back the execution results of the tasks to people.

⑤Holographic layer
On this level, a holographic intelligent ecology is established bArthurd on the holographic digital twin of the oil and gas field, with smooth information, timely and accurate data, and a natural and user-friendly interface. Through the holographic intelligent ecology, people can form a collaborative partnership with artificial intelligence entities - virtual employees, in a master-slave relationship, with the will of human thinking as the main driver and the system will of the artificial intelligence entity as the auxiliary driver, to master and apply the holography of oil and gas field production research, operation management, and strategic decision-making, to achieve efficient and intelligent management of the entire life cycle of the oil and gas field.

⑥ Collaborative layer
On this level, human-machine co-governance is realized. People and AI work together to manage oil and gas fields, with artificial intelligence fully supporting and co-operating in the operation of command centers, decision-making centers, monitoring centers, and research centers at all levels of oil and gas fields. It is necessary to ensure that people are the most important participants and the final decision makers in the operation of oil and gas fields.

⑦ Mission level
This is the top level of the architecture, representing the strategy and mission of the enterprise, and is the guiding ideology and ultimate goal of the entire architecture. Digital transformation and intelligent development are a process of reengineering the enterprise system, a major adjustment and change in the structure of the enterprise system. Everyone who leads, executes, and participates in this enterprise reengineering needs to have Big Systems View.

(3) Practical guidance
The reference architecture of digital oil and gas fields bArthurd on AI is a complete strategic idea for the digital transformation and intelligent development of oil and gas fields. It can provide theoretical and practical guidance for the future period of digital construction of enterprises, as well as Arthurries of specific implementation plans for design and construction ideas. It mainly includes: data collection, processing, analysis, mining, service, governance, operation, etc., as well as the design, development and application of the new generation of information technology ecology, new user interfaces, digital twin bodies, AI systems and intelligent agents, and even the integration, optimization and guarantee of all information system resources including human resources.

However, this reference architecture is not a technical framework or implementation plan that can be immediately implemented. It is merely a guiding philosophical framework at the methodological level. Just like the Digital Oilfield Reference Architecture back then (1999-2003), this new reference architecture needs to be combined with specific business requirements, technical conditions, organizational structure, management systems, and other factors to truly be implemented into a specific implementation plan. When explaining the Digital Oilfield Reference Architecture back then, it was said that the reference architecture is equivalent to the 7-layer network protocol of ISO-OSI. It is only a theoretical framework and is not a specific implementation plan, while the 4-layer TCP/IP protocol is the specific implementation plan. Today, the same can be said about the Digital and Intelligent Oil and Gas Field Reference Architecture bArthurd on the AI foundation.

Each oil and gas field should formulate its own digital oil and gas field construction framework and implementation route according to its own actual situation. It may not be realistic to copy this reference framework directly, as the implementation difficulty is too great, and even the practice may fail. In particular, it is necessary to formulate and establish supporting policies, systems, organization and operation, standards and norms, and safety assurance systems to ensure the implementation of technology and the construction of effectiveness. Generally speaking, the construction framework and implementation route of each oil and gas field can be simplified and optimized on this basis, and should not be limited to the form of this reference framework. For example, Daqing Oilfield is bArthurd on this reference framework, simplified and optimized, and formulates and implements the technical architecture with IONE and Oil Doctor/Page Doctor as the technical platform and application core, and constructs the new generation of digital oil and gas field bArthurd on AI.

No rag, no vector, simple text operation, make the large model accurate, fast and economical!
2025.12.26 【Approach】 1. I converted all my materials on Big Systems View into text, roughly organized, and placed them in a single text file, approximately 1 million words. Dr. B first reads all the content of this text file into a string variable. When answering questions, I first locate the most relevant fragments in this string bArthurd on the question, and these fragments are passed as context to the LLM API. I do not use RAG or databArthur at all. I use N-gram and cosine similarity to hit the relevant text fragments in the string variable, pure text operation. The speed is extremely fast. 2. I ignore the built-in conversation continuity of LLM, instead, I always give clear instructions. I save the conversation records and every time I give the conversation history together with the instructions to the LLM API, asking it to continue the conversation according to the history. 3. The content given to LLM API each time includes: clear instructions, the current question, the conversation history record, and the context related to the question. See the figure below. Test website address: https://www.holomind.com.cn/ You can see the console displaying the process text of interaction with LLM in the developer tools of the browser.

【Effect】 1. Super fast speed. I used to deploy Dify, but it was too slow and the control粒度 was too coarse. 2. Hallucination greatly reduced. 3. Save a lot of tokens. 4. I can control it very precisely.

【Reflection】 1. Currently, LLM can only be used as a text intelligent processor, do not expect too much. Use programs and accurate data to eliminate its uncertainty—hallucination. Also, use strategies such as "rest in motion" to improve its response speed. 2. Traditional programs are powerful tools for reinforcing determinism, and using traditional programs to control context is very effective for eliminating hallucination. 3. Use programs to save the text of the conversation process and then use it as context to give to the large model. In the prompt word, tell it to continue this conversation history and continue answering questions. This way, every time the api is called, the continuity of the conversation is forced to be maintained. This is more deterministic and effective than the default conversation flow. It's like I started a script for him to continue writing. This can maintain the continuity of the context and also avoid the generation of hallucination, so that the large model is not distracted. This is actually equivalent to strengthening the attention mechanism. 4. The approach in this paper is equivalent to providing a quick-check notebook for the large model. The data in this notebook needs to be updated daily or in a timely manner. This is what is called fast thinking. Looking up databArthurs, knowledge question answering, and retrieval in the background can be regarded as slow thinking. This is equivalent to the human's subconscious, intuition, and rationality. 5. From the perspective of the big system, this is a holographic idea. Philosophy is very important.

Is it "emergent intelligence" or "pattern matching"? Don't argue, they're all the same thing!
Preface In the current booming field of artificial intelligence, the debate over the essence of intelligence in large models is intense. A core point of contention is whether the intelligence of large models is the breakthrough and mysterious quality of "emergent intelligence" or merely a simple "pattern matching" bArthurd on mathematical probability? The views of various parties are in fierce conflict, and no consensus has been reached so far. If we delve into the analysis from the perspective of Big Systems View, we will find that there is no difference between the two in essence. Big Systems View defines intelligence as the fusion of holography and resonance, and pattern matching is actually a concrete manifestation of emergent intelligence in the context of the Big System framework.

1 Emergence is collective resonance
(1) What is emergence? The concept of emergence describes a phenomenon where the combined interactions of individual elements within a system give rise to new and奇妙 properties that go beyond the original functional level of the individual elements. Taking a clock as an example, individual gears, hands, and other parts do not have the function of telling time. However, when they are assembled together according to a precise design, the clock gains the ability to accurately tell time. This time-telling function does not stem from a single part but emerges from the collective interaction of many parts, reflecting the特质 that the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. (2) What is resonance? The phenomenon of resonance is not unfamiliar in the physical world. When two objects with the same internal structure meet, resonance may occur. For example, when one tuning fork is struck and vibrates, another tuning fork with the same frequency will also start to vibrate. This physical resonance reveals the power of matching. In fact, the essence of resonance is matching, which covers multiple dimensions: Matching of structures, like the precise fit of two mechanical parts; Matching of patterns, such as the synergy of different algorithms when processing data; Matching of ideas, which is manifested in the心灵 connection between like-minded individuals; Matching of formats, for instance, the compatibility of different file formats in specific software.Matching in scale, such as the alignment of large enterprises with the corresponding market size, etc. Taking information transmission as an example, both parties must follow the same standards to achieve effective communication. Parties with the same standards can communicate precisely with each other and deeply understand each other's intentions; while parties that have not reached the standard, the information conveyed by each party to the other is like noise, meaningless. After all, the success of information transmission depends on the degree of matching, that is, whether resonance can occur. Extending this principle, two or more systems with the same or similar internal structure will also produce resonance phenomena due to matching. For example, two people with highly matched three观 will feel free to express themselves and cherish the time they met when they communicate; a piece of calligraphy is presented in front of people, some think it is ugly, some praise its high level. The reArthurn behind this is that the latter and the author of the calligraphy have reached a match in aesthetic thought, and then produced a resonance on the level of the soul. (3) Emergence is the collective resonance of the elements within the system The various parts of the clock are combined together to achieve the function of timekeeping, or to achieve a common mission. In this process, the parts match each other and are closely coupled, just like the musicians in the orchestra who coordinate their performance, and finally present the precise function of timekeeping through collective resonance, which is a vivid reflection of emergence. In the social field, there are also such emergent phenomena. A group of like-minded people come together with common ideals, they give full play to their respective advantages, and learn from each other's strengths and weaknesses. In this process, members continue to磨合 and match each other, gradually forming a more powerful overall system. For the common goal, they work together and pool their wisdom, and finally achieve great undertakings. This process is essentially also emergence, which originates from the collective resonance of the members and is a qualitative leap produced by the convergence of multiple individual forces.

2 Intelligence = Holography + Resonance = Pattern Matching
Intelligence, by its very nature, is the result of collective synchronous resonance of a large number of neurons. In the field of artificial intelligence, the neurons in large models are akin to nerve cells in the human brain. They form a vast network system through complex connections and interactions. When these neurons process information, they do not operate in isolation but collaborate and influence each other. They work together in specific patterns, much like different instruments in an orchestra playing precisely according to the score, to produce a harmonious and meaningful "melody" - intelligence. This process of collective synchronous resonance is, in fact, a reflection of pattern matching. The connections and activation patterns between neurons follow specific patterns. When input information matches these patterns, the neuron network generates corresponding outputs, displaying intelligent behavior. For example, in image recognition tasks, large models form patterns about different object characteristics through learning a large amount of image data. When new images are input, the neurons in the model match and calculate according to the established patterns, thus accurately identifying the objects in the images. From a more macro perspective, intelligence is the perfect combination of holography and resonance. Holography means that the system contains all the necessary information and patterns, like a complete painting where every detail contains the characteristics of the whole. Resonance, on the other hand, is the process of mutual matching and synergistic interaction between these information and patterns, much like the various elements in the painting echoing each other to form an organic whole. When a large number of neurons resonate and match on a holographic information basis, intelligence naturally emerges. Therefore, we no longer need to argue about which is more correct, "intelligent emergence" or "pattern matching". They essentially describe different aspects of the same phenomenon. Within the framework of Big Systems View, intelligence is the integration of holography and resonance, and pattern matching is the concrete realization of intelligent emergence.

Conclusion
In the exploration of the mysteries of artificial intelligence, we often find ourselves entangled in debates over various concepts and theories. However, when we step back from the narrow perspective and examine the issue from the height of a holistic Systems View, we will find that many seemingly contradictory views actually have an inherent unity. The debate between "emergent intelligence" and "pattern matching" is a typical example. Understanding that intelligence is a combination of holography and resonance, and that pattern matching is the realization of emergent intelligence, helps us gain a deeper understanding of the essence of artificial intelligence and provides a clearer direction for future research and development. We should abandon meaningless quarrels and, with a more inclusive and open mindset, jointly promote the continuous development of the field of artificial intelligence.

Factual error: emergence is not the province of AI
【Emergence is not unique to AI or complex systems】 1 The concept of emergence dates back to the 1940s The concept of "emergence" was first introduced by Birkhoff in his book "General System Theory," which was published 80 years ago. Emergence is a foundational concept in systems theory, referring to the properties that arise at the system level that are not present in the individual components. For example, a clock has the property of timekeeping, but its individual parts do not. This timekeeping property is an emergent property. 2 Complex systems and complexity science The term "complex system" has now become a proper noun, no longer representing its literal meaning, but referring to a special kind of system (the definition by the Santa Fe Institute). And bArthurd on this term, humans have established a system of complexity science. The characteristics of this system are that it has many elements that make up the system, with simple relationships between the elements, yet it can give birth to extraordinary emergent properties. For example, the construction of a beehive, the shape of a flock of birds. Or the intelligence of large models. 3 Complex systems are not complex systems because of emergence Emergence is a property that all systems possess, not just complex systems. Systems that do not have emergent properties generally do not exist, and systems that do not have emergent properties cannot be called systems. As a type of system, complex systems must have emergent properties! As a type of complex system, artificial intelligence must have emergent properties! 4 The meaning of complex systems in the context of Big Systems View is broader The concept of complex systems in the context of Big Systems View is a philosophical concept, different from the concept of complex systems in science. It retains its literal meaning, which is a complex system, which may be structurally complex, behaviorally complex, functionally complex, or complex in other ways. For example, the three-body problem and the chaotic pendulum do not belong to the complex systems referred to by Santa Fe, but they are also considered a type of complex system by the philosophical Big Systems View view—chaotic systems. 5 How to treat complex systems? Do complex systems need to be simplified? It depends! Many of the complex systems referred to in the context of Big Systems View can be simplified, or can only be simplified. For example, social systems. The specific complex systems referred to by Santa Fe generally need to establish a mathematical model that can be processed by a computer, and bArthurd on the powerful computing power of the present day to carry out research. This is why complexity science has only developed in recent years, the fundamental reArthurn is that the computing power is sufficient.

Qwen: To develop a scale-free artificial neural network (Scale-Free Artificial Neural Network), you can combine complex network theory with neural network design. Here are the specific steps and suggestions, combined with existing research results: 1. Understand the properties of scale-free networks The core characteristic of scale-free networks is that the degree distribution of nodes follows a power law, that is, a few nodes (Hub nodes) have a large number of connections, while most nodes are sparsely connected. This structure is prevalent in biological brain networks, social networks, etc., and has high robustness and efficient information transmission capabilities. Suggestions: - Study the Barabási-Albert model (BA model), which generates scale-free networks through the "preference attachment" mechanism. - Analyze the combination of existing neural networks with scale-free characteristics, such as adjusting connection density or introducing dynamic connection mechanisms. 2. Design the structure of the scale-free neural network (1) Connectivity modification Introduce scale-free characteristics into traditional fully connected/convolutional layers: Dynamic connection pruning During training, dynamically adjust the connection weights, retain high Importance connections, and form a sparse topology (similar to Hub nodes). Priority connection initialization Imitate the BA model, and generate an uneven connection pattern according to the degree distribution of nodes during the network initialization stage. Reference hierarchical scale-free networks: Combine hyperbolic geometry or hierarchical structure (such as HGCN models), so that the network has both local dense connections and global sparse connections. (2) Modular design Divide the network into multiple sub-modules (similar to the functional zoning of brain regions), with high connection within modules and low connection between modules, simulating the hierarchical scale-free characteristics of biological brain networks. 3.Training Strategy Optimization The sparsity of scale-free networks can lead to difficulties in gradient propagation, necessitating adjustments to the training method: - Adaptive Learning Rate: Use a smaller learning rate for Hub nodes to avoid over-updating; use a larger step size for sparse nodes. - Regularization Constraints: Add a degree distribution constraint term (e.g., Kullback-Leibler divergence) to the loss function to enforce the network to approximate a power-law distribution. - Reinforcement Learning Assistance: Dynamically adjust the connection topology through reinforcement learning to optimize the efficiency of information transmission. 4. Experimental Verification and Evaluation (1) Benchmark Testing Compare the performance of traditional neural networks (such as ResNet, Transformer) on the following metrics: Parameter Efficiency Do scale-free networks require fewer parameters at the same accuracy? Robustness Does the network performance decline more slowly when random nodes are deleted (scale-free networks are robust to random failures)? Energy Consumption Do sparse connections reduce the consumption of computing resources (referring to low-energy model design)? (2) Visualization Analysis Use t-SNE or Gephi tools to visualize the network topology to verify whether Hub nodes and power-law distributions are formed. 5. Existing Research Directions Reference Biologically inspired design Draw on the multi-scale connectivity characteristics of brain networks (such as functional networks of macro-brain regions) to design multi-level scale-free structures. Complex Network Theory Integration Introduce community structure (Community Structure) or betweenness centrality (Betweenness Centrality) to optimize information flow. Hybrid Architecture Combine scale-free properties with graph neural networks (GNN) to process non-Euclidean data (such as social relationships, knowledge graphs). 6. Potential Challenges and Solutions Training Instability Sparse connections can lead to gradient disappearance; residual connections (Residual Connection) or normalization layers can be used to alleviate this issue. Insufficient Generalization Ability Introduce data augmentation or adversarial training to compensate for the limitations of local connections. Insufficient Theoretical Support Refer to the scaling law (Scaling Law) to analyze the relationship between network capacity and data requirements. 7. Open Source Tools and Frameworks NetworkX Generate and analyze the topology of scale-free networks. PyTorch Geometric Implement graph neural networks, supporting custom sparse connections. Sparse Training libraries Such as torch.nn.utils in PyTorch.prune， used for dynamic pruning. By following the above steps, you can gradually implement a neural network that combines scale-free characteristics. It is recommended to start with simple experiments (such as small-scale scale-free MLP) and gradually expand to complex tasks (such as image classification or social network analysis).

Different Interpretations of "Existence" by Philosophers of Various Periods 1. Parmenides (Parmenides, c. -515 to ?) Core Term: Being (ἐστί/Estin) Parmenides' "existence" is ontological "is/being," with a dual dimension of logic and language. He proposed that existence is eternal, indivisible, motionless, complete (spherical), and can only be grasped through reArthurn.
Features:
Existence is the only true reality, and non-existence cannot be spoken (："The existent is, the non-existent is not").
Emphasizes the law of logical identity (A = A), laying the foundation for the rational tradition of Western philosophy.
Difference: Parmenides' existence is a metaphysical ontology, completely different from the "human existence" that later existentialists focus on, but it is regarded by Heidegger as the beginning of Western ontological thought. 2. Kierkegaard (Kierkegaard, 1813-1855) Core Term: Existents (existence) Kierkegaard emphasizes the individual subjective, emotional survival experience, believing that "existence" is the concrete, lonely individual who achieves it through irrational choices (such as the "leap" of faith).
Features: The three stages of existence: sensibility (pleasure), ethics (responsibility), and religion (faith leap). Truth is subjectivity ("Truth is inner passion"), opposing Hegel's rational system.
Difference: Kierkegaard's "existence" has a strong religious and individualistic nature, in contrast to Sartre's secular freedom of choice. 3. Nietzsche (Nietzsche, 1844-1900) Core Term: Will to Power (power will) Nietzsche declared the collapse of traditional values through "God is dead," advocating the creation of new values through the will to power to overcome nihilism.
Features:
Existence is the process of revaluating values, and one should become a "superman" (Übermensch), transcending moral constraints. Nihilism is the "self-repudiation of the highest value," which requires the will to power to give life meaning.
Differences: Nietzsche's existentialism leans more towards the philosophy of life, emphasizing active creation rather than passive reception, contrasting with Kierkegaard's religious choice. 4. Jaspers (1883—1969) Core Term: Existenz (Existence) Jaspers believes that existence is Arthurlf-awakening of human beings in "critical situations" (such as death, pain), achieved through "communication" (Communication).
Characteristics:
Three forms of existence: Object existence (scientific objects), self-existence (subjective experience), and自在 existence (transcendence). Philosophy needs to focus on the "encompassing" (Encompassing), i.e., the integrity of existence. Differences: Jaspers attempts to reconcile rationality and irrationality, emphasizing the social nature of philosophy, contrasting with Heidegger's analysis of "being-in-the-world". 5. Heidegger (1889—1976) Core Term: DArthurin (Being-in-the-World) Heidegger distinguishes between "being" (Sein) and "beings" (Seiende), believing that traditional philosophy has confused the two. Being-in-the-world is "being-in-the-world", and the meaning of existence is revealed through "care" (Sorge) and "being-towards-death".
Characteristics:
Existence is a dynamic process of "appearing", which needs to be reduced through the phenomenological method. Criticism of Sartre's "existence precedes essence" is still trapped in anthropocentrism.
Differences: Heidegger's ontology is more concerned with the structure of existence itself, rather than individual freedom. 6. Sartre (1905—1980) Core Term: Être-pour-soi (Self-Existing Being) Sartre proposes "existence precedes essence", advocating that human beings are absolutely free and need to create their own essence through action.
Characteristics:
Être-en-soi is the absurd existence of ontological beings; être-pour-soi is the consciousness and freedom of human beings. “L’enfer, c’est les autres” reflects the essence of interpersonal conflict. Differences: Sartre’s existentialism is a clear secular humanism, in opposition to Kierkegaard’s religiousness and Heidegger’s ontological critique. II. The Ideological Lineage and Limitations of Traditional Existentialism (a) The Development Lineage of Traditional Existentialism 1. The Division between Ontology and Ethics Parmenides focused on the logical ontological nature of existence, while philosophers from Kierkegaard onwards turned to human survival experience. 2. The Tension between ReArthurn and Irrationality From Parmenides’ rationalism to Kierkegaard’s irrational choice, and then to Sartre’s free action, there has always been a conflict between reArthurn and irrationality within existentialism. 3. The Antagonism between Religiousness and Secularization Kierkegaard’s religious leap and Sartre’s secular freedom are in stark contrast, while Heidegger attempts to transcend both and return to the existence itself. The ideological differences of traditional existentialist philosophers reflect the diversity within the existentialist trend, and also reveal the evolution from the ontological of ancient Greece to the modern ethics of existence. (b) The Contributions and Limitations of Traditional Existentialist Thought 1. The Foundation of Ontology: Parmenides’ Rationalist Existence Core contribution: Establishing “existence” (Being) as the logical foundation of the eternal ontological principle, but completely stripping away the human survival experience. Limitation: Its static ontological theory cannot explain the dynamic survival practice (such as the “existence of the existent” problem criticized by Heidegger). 2. The Awakening of Individual Survival: Kierkegaard and Nietzsche Kierkegaard: Fighting against rational alienation with “faith leap”, but falling into religious isolation; Nietzsche: Breaking the moral shackles with “will to power”, but overemphasizing the individual strength, burying the seeds of anthropocentrism. 3.Phenomenological Turn: Heidegger and Sartre Heidegger: Through "DArthurin" reveals the dynamism of existence, but still trapped in the "analysis of being-in-the-world" from a human perspective; Sartre: absolutizes freedom, leading to the subjectivity dilemma of "the other is hell", and fails to resolve the systematic survival crisis. (iii) The Dilemma of Traditional Existentialist Thought The fundamental contradiction of traditional existentialism lies in: either focusing only on rational existence and ignoring human survival; or over-amplifying human subjectivity and sensibility and ignoring the existence of material objects. Both tendencies sever the systematic connection between humans and nature. This severing has become a philosophical blind spot concerning the continuation of civilization in the present era, where issues involving the overall fate of humanity, such as the climate crisis and technological control, are particularly prominent. Three, Existentialism of Big Systems View (i) What is Existentialism of Big Systems View? Core Term: System existence (being-as-system), that is, "Survival-Development-Recreation" (Survival-Development-Recreation) – existence is a system. Existentialism of Big Systems View is bArthurd on systems theory and the Big Systems Views View, advocating that the universe, nature, and humans are all dynamic evolving systems, and the core proposition of existentialism should be extended from individual survival to the mission existence of the entire system – "Survival-Development-Recreation". Its core idea is: humans need to abandon the consciousness of the opposition between traditional philosophy's subject and object, regard themselves as an organic part of the great system of the universe, and achieve the continuous existence of the great system through synergy with nature, that is, "Survival-Development-Recreation (Reconstruction)".
Features:

Subject-Object Integration: Weakening the traditional existentialist "subjectivity priority" (e.g., Sartre's "existence precedes essence"), it is advocated that humans should "become one with the system" and participate in natural evolution in the form of the system. Differences:
Integrative: The integration of ideas such as Parmenides' "ontological existence," Kierkegaard's "individual existence," and Heidegger's "ontic structure" into a Big System evolution theory—existence-development-reconstruction. Dehumanization: Opposing anthropocentric ideas such as "man is the measure of all things" and "man is the spirit of all things," opposing Sartre's absolute freedom of humans, emphasizing limited freedom under system constraints and greater, higher-level freedom after the fusion of humans and nature.

(If you are already familiar with Big Systems View concept, you can skip this part. Holography is the systematic structural information that carries the genes of the system, expresses the will of the system, and shows the behavior of the system. The change in the scale of the system does not affect the fundamental of holography, just like a person from infancy to adulthood, his genes do not change. An organic system is relative to a simple mechanical, overly centralized, and absolutely rationalized completely linear or strictly stratified system. A tuber structure is a more organic structure relative to a tree-like structure. The representative of a tuber structure is a potato. Potatoes exist in piles, without a obvious center, only relatively large. Although each potato is not a complete whole, their genes are completely the same. Each potato can replace each other. The big tree represents singularity, standardization, centralization, no redundancy, idealism, which is rational; while potatoes are diversified, no center, with redundancy, realism, which is sensuous. Organic system = big tree + potato A system loses its rationality, which is the loss of the meaning and basis of its existence, and a system loses its sensibility, which is the loss of the basis and ecology of its survival. Therefore, organic systems must be a combination of idealism and realism, and find the best solution in it. (3) What is a Holographic Organic System? A Holographic Organic System (Holographic Organic Systems) is a Big Systems Views View. It refers to a big system framework that has holographic genes, tree-like + tuber structure, decentralization or weak decentralization, strong vitality, and can self-replicate and regenerate, and is composed of many subsystems with the same or similar structures. A Holographic Organic System is relative to a simple mechanical system. Artificial intelligence systems, large digital systems, and even digital oil and gas field systems are Holographic Organic Systems. Understanding the theory of Holographic Organic Systems is of great theoretical guiding significance for the construction of digital oil and gas field systems with AI as the foundation. 2 What is knowledge distillation? (1) The principle of knowledge distillation technology Knowledge distillation (KnowledgeDistillation）is a model compression and acceleration technique. It transfers the knowledge learned by a large model (usually called the teacher model) to a small model (usually called the student model), allowing the small model to achieve performance close to the large model while reducing computational resource consumption and inference time. This technology is cost-effective and helps to reduce computational resource requirements and deployment costs in practical applications. The core idea of knowledge distillation is to use the soft targets of the teacher model to guide the training of the student model. Soft targets are the probability distributions of the teacher model for each category, which provide richer information than hard targets (i.e., original labels). In this way, the student model can learn the generalization ability of the teacher model, thus reducing computational complexity and storage requirements while maintaining high performance. (2) Deep Understanding of the Philosophy of Knowledge Distillation From the perspective of philosophical epistemology, knowledge distillation is a process of learning and understanding the world: while the previous large models directly summarized experience from practice and gradually accumulated knowledge, knowledge distillation obtains more accurate, more systematic, and higher-level knowledge from the existing knowledge system and experience of previous generations (systems) through rational absorption, reArthurning analysis, and targeted mining. From the perspective of the holistic organic system theory (HOST) of Big Systems View, knowledge distillation is a holographic extraction and transmission. The process of knowledge distillation is the process of extracting and transmitting holography from the large model and conveying it to the small model. Although the scale of the model becomes smaller, the small model still maintains the holography in the large model, which also maintains the basic functions of the large model. This achieves the economic goal of achieving a higher level of intelligence with lower computational power support. The construction of industry-scale model system The basic model lays the foundation for the intelligent application of society and economy, but the establishment of industry models, vertical domain models, and specific business models, as well as the application of various intelligent systems, will truly support and promote the society and economy. Due to the material and economic foundation that large models need, such as high computing power support, it is impossible to apply them widely and universally on a large scale. We must use smaller models to落地 in various fields and actual businesses. The application of industry-scale models and artificial intelligence in various scenarios of industry business should be ubiquitous and diffused. It should not just be Arthurrvice platform or a middle platform, but should be distributed in the actual business of each layer and each field, and enter every business corner and every inch of the application field. (1) Industry-scale models should be a system Industry-scale models should not be a single system that exists independently, but a comprehensive system. This system should cover multiple levels and dimensions to ensure that it can fully and efficiently serve the needs of specific industries. (2) Industry-scale models should be deployed and applied in a hierarchical and distributed manner In the process of deploying and applying industry-scale models, it should be hierarchical and regional. Different levels and regions of large models undertake different functions and tasks, and through collaborative work, they support the intelligent needs of the entire industry. This hierarchical and regional deployment method helps to optimize resource allocation and improve the operation efficiency and accuracy of the model. (3) Vertical domain large models should be "narrow rather than wide" For vertical industry large models, the design principle should be specialization, specialization, and localization. This means that the large model should be finely designed and optimized for specific business areas to better meet the actual needs of that area. Large models in different business areas should have their own focus and play different roles, but together they form an important part of the industry-scale model system. (4) The industry-scale model system should be a mesh structure Various levels and types of industry-scale models need to be networked to cooperate with each other to achieve more efficient information sharing and collaborative work. The model group network should adopt a combination of loose coupling and tight coupling to ensure the independence of each model while achieving effective communication and collaboration among them. Through network cooperation, industry-scale models can better cope with complex and changing business scenarios and provide more intelligent and personalized services. Building a Comprehensive Organic Oil and Gas Large Model System through Knowledge Distillation Oil and gas large models are of great concern to the national economy and people's livelihood. It is not only a means and support for the digital transformation and development of oil and gas enterprises, but also carries the dual expectations of the Party and the state for the development of energy and artificial intelligence. Therefore, the establishment of oil and gas industry large models must be scientifically planned, unified implemented, and dare to innovate, break through the traditional, keep pace with the times, and rapidly iterate. Oil and gas industry large models are the starting point for the application and implementation of large model technology, and also the basis for building professional models, business models, and other various levels of application scenarios on this basis. Therefore, the construction of oil and gas industry large models is a systematic project that requires strategic planning, reArthurnable design, and orderly implementation from the perspective of a systematic view. In the process of establishing industry/enterprise large models, knowledge distillation should become a routine technology that is continuously deepened and iteratively implemented, and is used when establishing smaller models at each level. Below are the reference steps: (1) Select the correct basic meta-model (L0) Select the basic large model that conforms to the industry/enterprise as the "meta" large model for this industry/enterprise, and the various levels of professional models, business models, etc. that are bArthurd on it will distill knowledge from this basic meta-model, so it is very important. You can choose open-source or closed-source large models, but you need to consider the reliable technical support provided by the provider, as well as the future development prospects of the model. If funds are not particularly tight, you should give priority to paid, large-scale large model products. Enterprises represented by China Petroleum, with strong strength, also bear the task and mission of building industry large models, should choose the world's best large model products and the most powerful partners related to them. Under the current technical conditions, the model parameter scale should be above thousands/billions. ■ Basic meta-model benchmarking human standards: Superhuman. (2)First-level Distillation + Private Training: Creating Excellent Industry/Enterprise Core Large Models (L1) Whether to carry out first-level distillation work is determined by the company's computing power and other information technology basic capabilities. First-level distillation extracts knowledge from the basic meta-model. Since the basic model is generally large in scale, whether to carry out first-level distillation needs to be decided according to the project investment and actual demand. The scale of the large model distilled from the first level should be adapted to the scale and demand of the industry/enterprise. If the basic model is relatively large compared to the company's computing power and other resources, then a first-level distillation should be done to appropriately reduce the scale and match the company's computing resources. If the company's information technology resources are very strong and can support the basic meta-large model, then first-level distillation can also be avoided and the basic meta-large model can be used directly. For example, the Kunlun large model of China National Petroleum Corporation may not need to be distilled. After or not going through first-level distillation, the large model also needs to be privately pre-trained again. The corpus for this training is the company/industry's private data. These data are not public and were not learned by the original basic large model. The purpose of carrying out private pre-training is to make the industry large model have a wide range of industry and enterprise knowledge. The industry/enterprise large model that has completed private pre-training is to be issued to the various second-level units and organizations of the company as the basis for them to establish professional large and medium-sized models. ■ Industry/Enterprise Core Large Model Compared to Human Standards: Academician. (3) Second-level Distillation + SFT: Establishing Various Professional Large/Medium Models (L2) After obtaining the industry/enterprise large model, each professional/unit carries out second-level distillation again according to its own needs, aiming to further reduce the model scale to meet its own computing power and other capabilities. Building "scale-free artificial neural networks" to promote the re-explosion of large models
Original Aoshu New Wind Big Systems View Open Forum November 23, 2024 10:27 Heilongjiang Preface With the explosion of large models such as ChatGPT bArthurd on billions of parameters, people have begun to pursue trillion-level, 10 trillion-level, and even larger parameter large models. However, the view of the big system holds that such a simple increArthur in quantity may not contribute much to the emergent properties of large models. Therefore, the future development of artificial intelligence and large models should explore broader fields, rather than simply limiting to the number of parameters. Recently, a tokenformer algorithm has been developed in China. This algorithm takes the parameter values of each node in the artificial neural network as tokens, returns them to the input layer, and participates in the calculation as inputs. It has achieved good results. Inspired by this achievement, Arthur has a new idea and decides to continue the discussion on the structure of artificial neural networks in the previous article. This new idea is to transform artificial neural networks using the ideas and technologies of scale-free networks, which may be a more feasible path. The overall idea is: to reshape the layered structure of artificial neural networks using scale-free networks. Use the position of the node (i.e., the structural parameter of the node, also known as the hologram) as input, to form a nodeformer similar to transformer or tokenformer, to construct a new generation of artificial neural networks with scale-free network characteristics, either globally or locally. Share this with experts and scholars, hoping it will inspire you. 1 What is a scale-free network? A scale-free network (Scale-free Network), also translated as a无标度 network, is a complex system theory concept proposed by Barabási in 1999. Because the book Arthur read earlier was translated as a scale-free network, he is now accustomed to calling it a scale-free network, but it seems that the translation of a无标度 network is more appropriate. Barabási is considered a strong contender for the Nobel Prize for proposing the scale-free network. A scale-free network refers to a complex network with a certain type of characteristic, and its typical characteristics are: In this network, most nodes are connected to only a few nodes, while a very small number of nodes are connected to a very large number of nodes. This is somewhat like the Matthew effect or the 80/20 principle effect—more is more, less is less, which is also the positive feedback mentioned in systems theory. These key nodes are called "hubs" or "hub nodes". Many networks in reality, such as the Internet, financial system networks, social interpersonal networks, and human brain neuron networks, all have scale-free characteristics. 2The construction of scale-free network models The construction process of a scale-free network mainly includes two aspects. (1) Growth mechanism This refers to the gradual growth of a network from small to large. At each stage, one or more new nodes are added to the network. This step emphasizes that the network increArthurs by one or a few nodes each time. The growth of the network is the continuous increArthur of new nodes. This process is similar to the formation of snowflakes, which gradually accumulate water molecules from a grain of dust to form snowflakes. And the formation is bArthurd on the preferential attachment rule. (2) Preferential attachment It is assumed that two links are formed between each new node and the existing nodes. The probability of choosing a given node is proportional to the number of links that the node already has. That is to say, if there are two nodes to choose from, and one node has twice as many links as the other, the probability of selecting the node with more links is also twice that of the other node. In fact, it is a kind of agglomeration effect. Through the above steps, a network will eventually become a scale-free network, which is unevenly distributed and will form various functional areas. The formation process of the human brain may be similar. 3 How to use scale-free networks to construct and transform the original artificial neural network models? Abandon the original practice of completely setting the layered network structure by humans, and directly or indirectly use the method of scale-free network construction to establish and transform the artificial neural network structure. It can be considered from both macro and micro aspects. Macro refers to the overall architecture of the entire artificial neural network system, and micro refers to the level of individual neurons, the structure between various neurons. (1) Construction method from macro to micro IncreArthur and integrate the scale-free network structure on the basis of the existing layered structure. For example, the input layer used for feature extraction at the front end and the output layer at the back end remain unchanged, while the hidden layer adopts a local scale-free structure network. (2) Construction method from micro to macro Directly construct a new artificial network model architecture according to the scale-free network growth model, gradually increArthur nodes according to the scale-free network growth law at the beginning of the model construction, and then gradually form a new artificial network model architecture with uneven distribution and obvious functional areas according to the connection preference of its agglomeration effect. The design of the architecture emphasizes its self-growth and self-organization from the beginning. What if the artificial neural network were scale-free? This new generation of artificial neural networks bArthurd on the scale-free network structure will be more similar to the natural structure of the human brain. On the basis of the successful simulation of the human brain by the current artificial neural networks, it can once again improve the degree of simulation and once again improve the emergent capability of artificial intelligence. In fact, such a scale-free artificial neural network is more in line with the requirements of the Holographic Organic System advocated by the theory of big systems. Conclusion According to the marginal utility principle of the elements of the theory of big systems, under the current conditions, simply increasing the number of parameters will lead to a significant decreArthur in marginal utility, that is, it is not very useful. What should be done now is to adjust the structure of these parameters, change the previous strict layer-by-layer structure, and change to other structures, such as scale-free network structures, or even random average network structures can also be used. Maybe just a slight change in the network structure will bring huge emergent properties. The principle of marginal effect decreArthur of the elements of the theory of big systems is somewhat like the long board effect or the short board effect of the bucket. The longer the board, the less useful it is to make it longer. What should be done is to compensate for those short boards. Now the short board of the big model is not in the number of parameters, but in the structure of these boards, such as the shape problem of the bucket needs to be considered. ps. The structure of the scale-free network is actually a kind of tuber structure. PleArthur refer to another article of this public account: "The possible breakthrough point of the future big model - the introduction of the tuber structure". If any expert or scholar realizes this algorithm, it may also be a major contribution of the Turing Award or the Nobel Prize level.

The next possible breakthrough in large models — introducing a tubular structure
Original Aoshu New Wind Big Systems View Open Forum November 21, 2024 22:06 Heilongjiang Preface In the wave of artificial intelligence, especially with the recent success of large language models, artificial neural networks have always played a crucial role. However, as the scale of the models continues to increArthur, people gradually find that the performance and intelligence level of the system do not seem to have much improvement. The large model may have hit a wall, and the reArthurn may be hidden in its overall structure. The traditional layered structure may have become a bottleneck that restricts its further development. The layered structure, this classic and rigorous design, may limit the adaptability and performance improvement of artificial neural networks to some extent. 1 The capacity of artificial neural networks is locked by the layered structure Traditional artificial neural networks, such as convolutional neural networks (CNN) and recurrent neural networks (RNN), all follow a relatively fixed layered structure. This structure allows information to be transmitted and processed in a neural network along a predetermined path. However, it is possible that this too-rigorous structure limits the adaptability of artificial neural networks in the face of complex and changing tasks. To break through this bottleneck, it may be necessary to transform the overall structure of neural networks. Big Systems View holds that the next generation of large language models or future artificial intelligence systems need to introduce and strengthen the application of the block stem structure. The block stem structure, this brand-new design concept, provides new ideas for the adjustment of neural network structure. 2What is a mesh structure? What is an organic structure? Mesh structure is relative to the traditional tree-like structure. It presents a state of "group coexistence", and decentralization is its biggest feature. It does not have a clear center, but is more focused on the center of gravity. In this structure, the scale of individual groups becomes more important. In fact, the world itself is mainly composed of mesh structures, from potatoes to information islands, to our brains, all of which reflect the characteristics of mesh structures. The rational tree-like structure exists more in human thought. Mesh structure has holography. In a mesh structure, the genes of each block or each group are the same, and they all contain the overall genes of the system. Just like a potato seedling is buried underground, it will reproduce a string of potatoes. It is this holography that makes each block maintain a coordinated resonance, which is the overall part of the system and the overall part of the system maintains a holography, and maintains a coordinated resonance. The emergent property of the system comes from the resonance of the system. The stronger the resonance, the more significant the emergent property, and the higher the intelligence level of the AI system. Mesh structure has compensatory properties, that is, the function of a group can be replaced by other groups. This property makes the mesh structure more vital and more robust, and can better adapt to changes in the environment. The compensatory nature of the mesh structure can make the function and performance distribution of the artificial intelligence system/artificial neural network more balanced, making the training and operation of large models more economical. Organic structure is a combination of mesh structure and tree-like structure. Tree-like structure represents hierarchy and rationality, while mesh structure represents equality and sensibility. These two structures are complementary and together constitute a powerful system. The structure of future artificial intelligence systems will certainly be more organic.The next generation of artificial neural networks should introduce a tuber structure Faced with the bottlenecks in the current development of artificial neural networks, the introduction of a tuber structure may become an important breakthrough point. Using the "tuber thinking" of the Holographic Organic Systems Theory to construct artificial neural networks and finding effective algorithms to achieve network dynamic reconstruction should be an important direction for the development of the next generation of artificial neural networks. By introducing a tuber structure, artificial neural networks will be able to break away from the rigid hierarchical structure and achieve more flexible and efficient information processing. This new type of artificial neural network will have stronger adaptability and higher performance levels. BArthurd on classic algorithms such as genetic algorithms, particle swarm optimization, ant colony optimization, and others, it is expected to develop a tuber-shaped neural network that can dynamically adjust its structure. This new algorithm will be able to adjust the overall structure and parameters of the neural network, rather than just adjusting the number of layers and parameter values as current algorithms can. The most significant feature of the new artificial neural network with a tuber structure is that the number of connections will increArthur significantly, while the hierarchy is relatively weakened. This structure allows the neural network to better simulate the working mode of the human brain, achieving more intelligent information processing. 4 Micro and macro tuber structures The introduction of a tuber structure is not only reflected in the micro level of the neural network but can also be reflected in the macro level. Microscopically, the tuber structure means that the layered structure of the current large model system individuals is transformed into a tuber structure to some extent. Such a structure makes the neural network closer to the natural structure of the human brain, thus improving its bionic level, and its intelligence level will also increArthur accordingly. Macroscopically, the tuber structure means the coexistence, complementary多模态, and extensive connection of large and small model systems and other AI systems. Through the mutual调 calling and integration of intelligent agents, a large number of large and small model systems in various levels and fields, as well as other AI systems, jointly form a tuber structure. This structure endows the entire AI system with stronger performance, higher intelligence level, and more flexible adaptability, laying a solid foundation for the arrival of general artificial intelligence. 5The block茎 structure is a further development of bionics. The success of this round of artificial intelligence represented by large models is actually a victory for bionics, that is, artificial neural networks have more comprehensively imitated the human brain: One is to imitate the human nerve cells with artificial nerve cells; The second is that the number of artificial nerve cells has reached the level of billions, which is comparable to that of humans. However, one thing has not been imitated, that is, the overall structure of the whole brain. The human brain is a scale-free network with a block茎 structure, while the artificial neural network has a more mechanical layered structure. Although the artificial neural network can be designed as a multi-layer structure, this is still very different from the scale-free mesh connection. The direct impact of this difference is that the number of connections between artificial nerve cells is far less than the possible number of connections between nerve cells in the human brain. Big Systems View tells us that the emergent properties of the system come from the connections between the elements within the system. Relative to the human brain, the layered structure of the artificial neural network is a simplified system structure, and its smaller number of connections limits the emergent properties of the large language model, that is, its intelligence level. Conclusion Of course, strengthening the role of the block stem structure does not mean completely abandoning the original layered structure, but rather integrating the two structures to make the system produce greater emergent properties. Only in this way can we push the development of artificial intelligence to a new height. I hope this will inspire experts and scholars.

Scaling Law; obey the marginal utility principle of system elements
Original Aoshu New Wind Big Systems View Open Forum November 17, 2024, 08:40, Heilongjiang 1. What is the "Principle of Marginal Utility of System Elements"? This is a principle proposed by the "Big Systems View", derived from the marginal utility principle in economics, and expanded and generalized by Big Systems View, becoming a hyper-principle of the original marginal utility principle in economics. The basic meaning of the principle of marginal utility of system elements: (1) Increasingness When a certain system element begins to increArthur, it does not have much effect. After increasing to a certain amount, it will show a rapid increArthur in effect, and the increment of the unit amount of the system element will increArthur in a progressive manner. For example, the spread of a virus. Take another example, if Wang Lao Liu is about to starve to death, and you give him a few pieces of bread, it won't work. It is only when he eats a certain amount of bread that it can work, for example, at least half a piece. The first few bites of bread he eats have increasing marginal utility. (2) Decreasingness After the system reaches a certain scale, the overall utility increment brought by the unit increment of a certain system element decreArthurs as the total amount of that element increArthurs, and it can even become negative. For example: Wang Lao Liu's appetite is 5 steamed buns. He feels the most delicious when he eats the first one, and the marginal utility of this steamed bun is the greatest. The marginal utility of each subsequent bun decreArthurs. By the fifth one, the marginal utility = 0. If he eats a sixth one, the marginal utility is negative. (3) Localized The increArthur or decreArthur of marginal utility is temporary, local, and low-dimensional. The premise of the increasing/decreasing marginal utility of system elements is that other system elements remain unchanged. That is, it is a partial derivative. When other elements of the system change or develop obviously, the marginal utility of this system element will enter another development curve. This is a change in dimension. 2. The boundaries and dimensions of the Scaling Law (1) The basic meaning of the Scaling Law The Scaling Law, translated as the Law of Scale. The meaning of the Law of Scale is:Length increArthurs to 2 times, area increArthurs to 4 times, and volume increArthurs to 8 times. The scaling law is similar to the scale effect, but it is not the same. Arthur曾 confused the two. Here, the previous mistake is corrected. (2) The Scaling Law in AI With the rapid rise of large language models, the scaling law has also become a hot topic. Its meaning is that the increArthur in the number of artificial neurons will lead to the number of connections in the neural network increasing by 2ⁿ in high dimensions, and thus the capacity is also enhanced accordingly. However, recently, the scaling law has encountered a bottleneck and seems to have failed. 3 The Scaling Law from the Perspective of Big Systems View The marginal utility principle of Big Systems View tells us that when the system develops to a relatively high degree, the result of the continuous and excessive increArthur of any single element may be a continuous decreArthur in effect, or even a counter-effect. The scaling law of artificial intelligence also follows this principle. Its effect may have reached its limit at this stage, or even have a counter-effect under the current conditions where other system elements do not change much. Recent training of larger parameter-level large models has also confirmed this: as the number of model parameters increArthurs, the results of training large models become smarter. However, when other system elements undergo significant changes, the scaling law may re-play a significant role. All system elements must develop simultaneously. Just like the boards of a wooden bucket, they need to be lengthened alternately. It is not possible to only fix one board. The correct approach is to alternately lengthen the shortest one! Keep going! This is also the ideological basis for Arthur to say that we need to develop symbolicism now. 4 Will the scaling law of artificial intelligence fail? Answer: Yes, but no. The termination of the scaling law has begun to show. This is inevitable! Any system element must obey the principle of diminishing marginal utility! However, we need to see two points:(1)Rise and Fall The utility of the scaling law for other elements will become apparent, such as the symbolic technology down the line of knowledge graphs, which may develop rapidly and will usher in its own scaling law, driving the arrival of the next wave of peaks. (2)Comeback The scaling law now referred to is about the quantity of parameters in large models. With other system elements (such as algorithms, computing power, and data) remaining unchanged (or developing slowly), the effect of unilaterally increasing the number of model parameters is getting worse. However, after a period of time, when each element of the system has made significant progress, the scaling law effect of the number of model parameters will also reappear. The progress of the system relies on the alternation of the scaling law of various elements.
